question: Question 1 Two resistors are connected in a circuit loop of area [latex]5 \mathrm{~m}^{2}[/latex], as shown in the figure below. The circuit loop is placed on the [latex]x-y[/latex] plane. When a time-varying magnetic flux, with fluxdensity [latex]\mathrm{B}(\mathrm{t})=0.5 \mathrm{t}[/latex] (in Tesla), is applied along the positive z-axis, the magnitude of current I (in Amperes, rounded off to two decimal places) in the loop is __________ .
solution:
Given: Loop area, [latex] A = 5\ \text{m}^2 [/latex] Magnetic field, [latex] B(t) = 0.5t\ \text{T} [/latex] Total resistance in the loop = [latex]2\ \Omega + 2\ \Omega = 4\ \Omega[/latex] We use Faraday's Law of electromagnetic induction:
[latex] \mathcal{E} = -\frac{d\Phi}{dt} [/latex]
where [latex] \Phi = B(t) \cdot A [/latex] is the magnetic flux. So,
[latex] \Phi(t) = B(t) \cdot A = 0.5t \cdot 5 = 2.5t [/latex] [latex] \frac{d\Phi}{dt} = \frac{d}{dt}(2.5t) = 2.5\ \text{V} [/latex] So, the induced EMF is:
[latex] \mathcal{E} = -2.5\ \text{V} [/latex] (The negative sign indicates direction, but we are interested in magnitude of current) Now, using Ohm's Law:
[latex] I = \frac{|\mathcal{E}|}{R} = \frac{2.5}{4} = 0.625\ \text{A} [/latex]

question: Question 2 A [latex]50 \Omega[/latex] lossless transmission line is terminated with a load [latex]\mathrm{Z}_{\mathrm{L}}[/latex] of [latex](50-\mathrm{j} 75) \Omega[/latex]. If the average incident power on the line is 10 mW , then the average power delivered to the load (in mW , rounded off to one decimal place) is __________ .
solution:
Step 1: Characteristic Impedance
Given:
[latex] Z_0 = 50\ \Omega [/latex] (lossless line) [latex] Z_L = 50 - j75\ \Omega [/latex] Incident power = [latex] P_{\text{inc}} = 10\ \text{mW} [/latex] Step 2: Reflection Coefficient
Reflection coefficient [latex] \Gamma = \frac{Z_L - Z_0}{Z_L + Z_0} [/latex] First compute:
[latex] Z_L + Z_0 = (50 - j75) + 50 = 100 - j75 [/latex] [latex] Z_L - Z_0 = (50 - j75) - 50 = -j75 [/latex] So:
[latex] \Gamma = \frac{-j75}{100 - j75} [/latex] Multiply numerator and denominator by the complex conjugate of the denominator:
[latex] \Gamma = \frac{-j75 \cdot (100 + j75)}{(100 - j75)(100 + j75)} [/latex] Numerator:
[latex] -j75(100 + j75) = -j7500 - j^2 75 \cdot 75 = -j7500 + 5625 [/latex] Denominator:
[latex] 100^2 + 75^2 = 10000 + 5625 = 15625 [/latex] So:
[latex] \Gamma = \frac{5625 - j7500}{15625} = 0.36 - j0.48 [/latex] Step 3: Reflected Power
[latex] |\Gamma|^2 = (0.36)^2 + (0.48)^2 = 0.1296 + 0.2304 = 0.36 [/latex] So, reflected power = [latex] P_{\text{ref}} = |\Gamma|^2 \cdot P_{\text{inc}} = 0.36 \cdot 10 = 3.6\ \text{mW} [/latex] Step 4: Delivered Power
[latex] P_{\text{delivered}} = P_{\text{inc}} - P_{\text{ref}} = 10 - 3.6 = \boxed{6.4\ \text{mW}} [/latex]

Question 7 Let [latex]\hat{i}[/latex] and [latex]\hat{j}[/latex] be the unit vectors along [latex]x[/latex] and [latex]y[/latex] axes, respectively and let [latex]A[/latex] be a positive constant. Which one of the following statements is true for the vector fields [latex]\vec{F}_{1}=A(\hat{i} y+\hat{j} x)[/latex] and [latex]\vec{F}_{2}=A(\hat{i} y-\hat{j} x) ?[/latex]
solution:
For an electrostatic field, [latex]\nabla \times \bar{F}=0[/latex] [latex]
\begin{aligned}
& \bar{F}_{1}=A[y \hat{i}+x \hat{j}] \\
& \Rightarrow \\
& \Delta \times \bar{F}_{1}=A\left|\begin{array}{ccc}
\hat{i} & \hat{j} & \hat{k} \\
\partial / \partial x & \partial / \partial y & \partial / \partial z \\
y & x & 0
\end{array}\right| \\
& =A[0 \hat{i}-0 \hat{j}+(1-1) \hat{k}] \\
& =0 \\
& \bar{F}_{2}=A[y \hat{i}-x \hat{j}] \\
& \Rightarrow \\
& \Delta \times \bar{F}_{2}=A\left|\begin{array}{ccc}
\hat{i} & \hat{j} & \hat{k} \\
\partial / \partial x & \partial / \partial y & \partial / \partial z \\
y & -x & 0
\end{array}\right| \\
& =A[0 \hat{i}-0 \hat{j}+(-1-1) \hat{k}] \\
& =-2 A \hat{k}
\end{aligned}
[/latex] Hence, [latex]\bar{F}_{1}[/latex] is electrostatic, [latex]\bar{F}_{2}[/latex] is not electrostatic.

options.D: Neither [latex]\vec{F}_{1}[/latex] nor [latex]\vec{F}_{2}[/latex] is an electrostatic field.

question: Question 8 Consider a lossless transmission line terminated with a short circuit as shown in the figure below. As one moves towards the generator from the load, the normalized impedances [latex]z_{\text {in } A}, z_{\text {in } B}, z_{\text {in } C}[/latex] and [latex]z_{\text {in } D}[/latex] (indicated in the figure) are _____
solution:
[latex]Z_{s / c}=j Z_{0} \tan \beta l[/latex]. [latex]\Rightarrow[/latex] Normalized impedance, [latex]
\begin{aligned}
& \bar{Z}_{S / C}=\frac{Z_{S / C}}{Z_{0}}=j \tan \beta l \\
& \bar{Z}_{\text {in } A}=j \tan \left(\frac{2 \pi}{\lambda} \cdot \frac{\lambda}{8}\right)=j \tan (\pi / 4)=j 1 \Omega \\
& \bar{Z}_{\text {in } B}=j \tan \left(\frac{2 \pi}{\lambda} \cdot \frac{\lambda}{4}\right)=\infty \\
& \bar{Z}_{\text {in } C}=j \tan \left(\frac{2 \pi}{\lambda} \cdot \frac{3 \lambda}{8}\right)=-j 1 \Omega \\
& \bar{Z}_{\text {in } D}=j \tan \left(\frac{2 \pi}{\lambda} \cdot \frac{\lambda}{2}\right)=0
\end{aligned}
[/latex]

options.A: [latex]z_{\text {in } A}=+0.4 j \Omega, z_{\text {in } B}=\infty, z_{\text {in } C}=-0.4 j \Omega, z_{\text {in } D}=0[/latex]
options.B: [latex]z_{\text {in } A}=\infty, z_{\text {in } B}=+0.4 j \Omega, z_{\text {in } C}=0, z_{\text {in } D}=+0.4 j \Omega[/latex]
options.C: [latex]z_{\text {in } A}=-1 j \Omega, z_{\text {in } B}=0, z_{\text {in } C}=+1 j \Omega, z_{\text {in } D}=\infty[/latex]
options.D: [latex]z_{\text {in } A}=+1 j \Omega, z_{\text {in } B}=\infty, z_{\text {in } C}=-1 j \Omega, z_{\text {in } D}=0[/latex]

question: Question 14 Consider a narrow band signal, propagating in a lossless dielectric medium [latex]\left(\epsilon_{r}=4, \mu_{r}=1\right)[/latex], with phase velocity [latex]v_{p}[/latex] and group velocity [latex]v_{g}[/latex]. Which of the following statement is true? ( [latex]c[/latex] is the velocity of light in vacuum.)
solution: Phase velocity, [latex]V_{p}=\frac{\omega}{\beta}=\frac{\omega}{\omega \sqrt{\mu \epsilon}}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{\mu_{0} \epsilon_{0}}}, \frac{1}{\sqrt{\mu_{r} \epsilon_{r}}}=\frac{C}{\sqrt{\mu_{r} \epsilon_{r}}}[/latex] [latex]\therefore \quad V_{p} \lt C[/latex] Group velocity, [latex]V_{g}=\frac{d \omega}{d \beta}=\frac{V_{p}}{1-\frac{\omega}{V_{p}} \frac{d V_{p}}{d \omega}}[/latex] Here, [latex]\quad V_{p} \neq f(\omega)[/latex] [latex]\therefore \quad V_{g}=V_{p} \lt C[/latex] Hence, [latex]\quad V_{p} \lt C[/latex] [latex]\quad \quad V_{g} \lt C[/latex]

question:
Question 15 In an electrostatic field, the electric displacement density vector, [latex] \vec{D}  [/latex], is given by [latex] \vec{D}(x,y,z)=(x^3\vec{i}+y^3\vec{j}+xy^2\vec{k})C/m^2  [/latex] ,
where [latex] \vec{i},\vec{j},\vec{k}  [/latex] are the unit vectors along x-axis, y-axis, and z-axis, respectively.
Consider a cubical region R centered at the origin with each side of length 1 m, and
vertices at ([latex]\pm 0.5 m, \pm 0.5 m, \pm 0.5 m  [/latex]). The electric charge enclosed within R is
_________ C (rounded off to two decimal places).
solution: [latex]\vec{D}(x,y,z)=(x^3\vec{i}+y^3\vec{j}+xy^2\vec{k})c/m^2[/latex] [latex]Q_{enc.}=\int _v \rho _v\cdot dV=\int (\triangledown \cdot \vec{D})dV[/latex] [latex]\triangledown \cdot \vec{D}=3x^2+3y^2[/latex] [latex]dV=dxdydz[/latex] [latex]\therefore \; Q_{enc.}=\int _v 3(x^2+y^2)dxdydz =3\left [ \int_{-0.5}^{0.5} x^2 dx  \int_{-0.5}^{0.5}dy \int_{-0.5}^{0.5} dz+\int_{-0.5}^{0.5}dx\int_{-0.5}^{0.5}y^2dy\int_{-0.5}^{0.5}dz \right ][/latex] [latex] =3\left [ \frac{x^3}{3}|_{-0.5}^{0.5} \times 1 \times 1 + \frac{y^3}{3}|_{-0.5}^{0.5} \times 1 \times 1\right ] =0.25+0.25=0.5C[/latex]

As we know, wave equation is given by [latex] \frac{\partial^2 f(x,t)}{\partial x^2}=\frac{C^2d^2f(x,y)}{dt^2}[/latex] Here, option (A) and (C) are satisfying the above

Question 19 An antenna with a directive gain of [latex]6\text{ dB}[/latex]
 is radiating a total power of [latex]\text{16 kW}[/latex]. The amplitude of the electric field in free space at a distance of [latex]\text{8 km}[/latex]
 from the antenna in the direction of [latex]\text{6 dB}[/latex]
 gain (rounded off to three decimal places) is  ______  [latex]\text{V/m}[/latex]
.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} G_{d}(\mathrm{~dB}) &=10 \log _{10}\left(G_{d}\right) \\ \Rightarrow\qquad 6 &=10 \log _{10} G_{d} \\ \Rightarrow\qquad G_{d} &=10^{0.6} \\ G_{d} &=3.981 \\ E_{m} &=\frac{\sqrt{60 G_{d} P_{\text {rad }}}}{r} \\ E_{m} &=\frac{\sqrt{60\left(16 \times 10^{3}\right)(3.981)}}{8 \times 10^{3}}=0.244(\mathrm{~V} / \mathrm{m}) \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 20 A standard air-filled rectangular waveguide with dimensions [latex]\text{a=8 cm, b=4 cm}[/latex], operates at [latex]\text{3.4 GHz}[/latex]. For the dominant mode of wave propagation, the phase velocity of the signal in [latex]v_{p}[/latex]. The value (rounded off to two decimal places) of [latex]v_{p}/c[/latex], where c denotes the velocity of light, is _____
solution: [latex]f_{c 10}=\frac{c}{2 a}=\frac{3 \times 10^{8}}{2\left(8 \times 10^{-2}\right)}=1.875 \mathrm{GHz}[/latex] Guide phase velocity,[latex] V_{p}=\frac{C}{\sqrt{1-\left(\frac{f_{C 10}}{f}\right)^{2}}} [/latex] [latex] \frac{V_{p}}{C}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\left(\frac{f_{C 10}}{f}\right)^{2}}}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\left(\frac{1.875}{3.4}\right)^{2}}}=1.198[/latex]

question: Question 23 The refractive indices of the core and cladding of an optical fiber are 1.50 and 1.48, respectively. The critical propagation angle, which is defined as the maximum angle that the light beam makes with the axis of the optical fiber to achieve the total internal reflection, (rounded off to two decimal places) is _____ degree.
solution: Given that Refractive index of core [latex]\eta_{1}=1.50 [/latex] Refractive index of clad [latex]\eta_{2}=1.48 [/latex] Critical propagation angle [latex]\left(\theta_{P}\right)[/latex] [latex] \theta_{P}=\sin ^{-1}\left[ \frac{ \sqrt{\eta_{1}^{2}-\eta_{2}^{2}}}{\eta_{1}}    \right]=\sin ^{-1} \left[  \frac{  \sqrt{1.5^{2}-1.48^{2}} }{1.5} \right] =9.37[/latex]

question:
Question 24 Consider the vector field [latex]F\:=\:a_{x}\left ( 4y-c_{1}z \right )+a_y\left ( 4x + 2z\right )+a_{z}\left ( 2y +z\right )[/latex] in a rectangular coordinate system (x,y,z) with unit vectors [latex]a_{x},\:a_{y}[/latex] and [latex]a_{z}[/latex]. If the field F is irrotational (conservative), then the constant [latex]c_{1}[/latex]
 (in integer) is _________________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \nabla \times \vec{F}&=0\\ \left|\begin{array}{ccc} i & j & k \\ \frac{\partial}{\partial x} & \frac{\partial}{\partial y} & \frac{\partial}{\partial z} \\ 4 y-c_{1} z & 4 x+2 z & 2 y+z \end{array}\right|&=0\\ =i(2-2)-j\left(0+c_{1}\right)+k(4-4)=0 \\ c_{1} &=0 \end{aligned}[/latex]

For [latex]z \lt  0[/latex] medium has [latex] \epsilon_{r 2}=1 ; \mu_{r 2}=4[/latex] [latex] \Gamma=\frac{\eta_{2}-\eta_{1}}{\eta_{2}+\eta_{1}}=\frac{120 \pi(2)-120 \pi}{120 \pi(2)+120 \pi}=\frac{1}{3}[/latex]

question: Question 26 The magnetic field of a uniform plane wave in vacuum is given by [latex]\vec{H}(x,y,z,t)=(\hat{a}_x+2\hat{a}_y+b\hat{a}_z) \cos (\omega t+3x-y-z)[/latex] The value of b is _____
solution: For uniform plane wave [latex]\hat{a}_{H}\cdot \hat{a}_{\rho }=0[/latex] [latex]\hat{a}_{H}[/latex]is unit vector in magnetic field direction [latex]\hat{a}_{\rho }[/latex] is unit vector in power flow direction [latex]\hat{a}_{H }=\frac{1\hat{a}_{x}+2\hat{a}_{y}+b\hat{a}_{z}}{\sqrt{1^{2}+2^{2}+b^{2}}} [/latex] [latex]\hat{a}_{\rho }=\frac{-3\hat{a}_{x}+\hat{a}_{y}+\hat{a}_{z}}{\sqrt{3^{2}+1^{2}+1^{2}}}[/latex] [latex] \hat{a}_{H}\cdot \hat{a}_{\rho }=0 (\hat{a}_{x}+2\hat{a}_{y}+b\hat{a}_{z})\cdot (-3\hat{a}_{x}+\hat{a}_{y}+\hat{a}_{z})=0[/latex] [latex] -3+2+b=0[/latex] [latex] b=1[/latex]

question:
Question 27 For an infinitesimally small dipole in free space, the electric field [latex]E_\theta[/latex] in the far field
is proportional to [latex](e^{-jkr}/r) \sin \theta[/latex], where [latex]k = 2 \pi /\lambda[/latex]. A vertical infinitesimally small
electric dipole ([latex]\delta l \lt \lt \lambda[/latex]) is placed at a distance [latex]h(h \gt 0)[/latex] above an infinite ideal
conducting plane, as shown in the figure. The minimum value of h, for which one
of the maxima in the far field radiation pattern occurs at [latex]\theta =60^{\circ}[/latex], is
solution:
[latex]\begin{aligned}\left | \text{Total E }\right |&=\left | (E_{\text{single element}}) \right | \left | (A.F.) \right | \\ \left | (A.F.) \right |&=\frac{\sin\left ( N\frac{\psi }{2} \right )}{\sin (\frac{\psi }{2})}=\frac{\sin \left ( 2\frac{\psi }{2} \right )}{\sin \left ( \frac{\psi }{2} \right )} \\ & =\frac{2\sin \left ( \frac{\psi }{2} \right )\cos (\frac{\psi }{2})}{\sin \frac{\psi }{2}} \\ & =2\cos (\frac{\psi }{2})\\  \left | A.F_{N} \right | &=\frac{A.F}{A.F_{max}}=\frac{2\cos (\frac{\psi }{2})}{2} \\ &=\left | \cos \left ( \frac{\psi }{2} \right ) \right | \\
\text{where, }\psi &=\beta d\cos \theta =\frac{2\pi }{\lambda }(2h)\cos \theta  \\ \left.\begin{matrix} \left | A.F_{N} \right |_{\theta =60^{\circ}} \end{matrix}\right|& =\left | \cos (\frac{2\pi }{\lambda }h\cos 60^{\circ}) \right |\\ &=\left | \cos \left ( \frac{\pi h}{\lambda } \right ) \right |\\ \cos \theta  \text{ is maximum ,where   } \theta &=n\pi \;\; n=0,1,2..\\ \frac{\pi h}{\lambda }&=n\pi \Rightarrow h=n\lambda \\ \Rightarrow \; \text{For } n=1,  \;\; h_{min}&=\lambda \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:

Question 29 The impedances Z=jX, for all X in the range ([latex]-\infty ,\infty[/latex]), map to the Smith chart as
solution: For given impedance Normalized impedance is [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{Z}{Z_{0}}&=\frac{jX}{Z_{0}}\\ Z&=jX \\ \Rightarrow \; Z&=0+jX \end{aligned}[/latex] Normalized Resistance  [latex]=0 \; \Rightarrow \;  r=0[/latex] [latex]X=-\infty \text{ to } \infty[/latex] [latex]r=0[/latex] and X from [latex]-\infty \, to\, \infty[/latex] is a unit circle (radius 1) and centre (0,0) on a complex reflection coeffient plane:

question: Question 30 A rectangular waveguide of width w and height h has cut-off frequencies for [latex]TE_{10} \; and \;TE_{11}[/latex] modes in the ratio 1:2. The aspect ratio w/h, rounded off to two decimal places, is ___________
solution: [latex]f_{c m n}=\frac{c}{2} \sqrt{\left(\frac{m}{a}\right)^{2}+\left(\frac{n}{b}\right)^{2}}[/latex] For TE mode [latex] f_{c10}=\frac{c}{2 w} \quad\ldots(i)[/latex] and For [latex]TE_{11}[/latex] mode. [latex] \begin{aligned} f_{c11} &=\frac{c}{2} \sqrt{\frac{1}{w}^{2}+\left(\frac{1}{h}\right)^{2}} &\ldots(i)\\ &=\frac{c}{2 w} \sqrt{1+\left(\frac{w}{h}\right)^{2}} &\ldots(ii)\\ \text{given}\quad\frac{f_{c10}}{f_{11}} &=\frac{1}{2} &\ldots(iii) \end{aligned}[/latex] put (i). (in) in (ii) [latex] \Rightarrow \frac{\frac{c}{2 w}}{\frac{c}{2 w} \sqrt{1+\left(\frac{w}{h}\right)^{2}}}=\frac{1}{2} \Rightarrow \sqrt{1+\left(\frac{w}{h}\right)^{2}}=2[/latex] On solving above equation, we get, [latex] \frac{w}{h}=\sqrt{3}=1.732[/latex]

question: Question 31 The dispersion equation of a waveguide,which relates the wavenumber kto the frequency [latex]\omega[/latex], is [latex]k(\omega) =(1/c)\sqrt{\omega ^2 -{\omega _0}^2}[/latex] where the speed of light [latex]c=3 \times 10^8[/latex] m/s, and [latex]\omega_0[/latex] is a constant.  If the group velocity is [latex]2 \times 10^8[/latex] m/s, then the phase velocity is
solution: By definition [latex]v_{p}=\frac{\omega}{\beta}=\frac{\omega}{k} [/latex] where, [latex]k(\omega)=\left(\frac{1}{c}\right) \sqrt{\omega^{2}-\omega_{0}^{2}} \quad [/latex](given) [latex] \therefore v_{p}=\frac{c}{\sqrt{1-\left(\frac{\omega_{0}}{\omega}\right)^{2}}}[/latex] by definition, [latex] \begin{aligned} v_{g} &=\frac{d \omega}{d \beta}=\frac{d \omega}{d k} \\ &=\frac{d k}{d \omega}=\frac{1}{c} \frac{1}{2 \sqrt{\omega^{2}-\omega_{0}^{2}}} \times 2 \omega \\ \text{or}\quad v_{g} &=c \sqrt{1-\left(\frac{\omega_{0}}{\omega}\right)^{2}}\\ \because \quad v_{p} \cdot v_{g} &=c^{2} \\ \therefore \quad v_{p} &=\frac{c^{2}}{v_{g}}=\frac{\left(3 \times 10^{8}\right)^{2}}{2 \times 10^{8}} \\ &=4.5 \times 10^{8} \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{sec} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 32 Two identical copper wires W1 and W2, placed in parallel as shown in the figure, carry currents I and 2I, respectively, in opposite directions. If the two wires are separated by a distance of 4r, then the magnitude of the magnetic field [latex]\vec{B}[/latex] between the wires at a distance r from W1 is
solution: Magnetic flux density [latex](\vec{B})[/latex] at r distance due to infinite line carrying current I is [latex]|\vec{B}|=\frac{\mu_{0} I}{2 \pi \rho} .[/latex] [latex] \vec{B} [/latex] at r distance due to [latex]W_{1}[/latex] wire [latex] =\left|\vec{B}_{1}\right|=\frac{\mu_{0} I}{2 \pi r}\qquad \ldots(i)[/latex] [latex] \vec{B} [/latex] at 3r distance due to [latex]W_{2}[/latex] wire [latex] =\left|\vec{B}_{2}\right|=\frac{\mu_{0}(2 I)}{2 \pi(3 r)}\qquad \ldots(ii)[/latex] From right hand thumb rule, [latex]\vec{B} [/latex] due to both lines add in between conductors. [latex] \begin{aligned} {So,}\qquad |\vec{B}|&=\left|\vec{B}_{1}\right|+\left|\vec{B}_{2}\right|\\ \therefore \qquad |\vec{B}|&=\frac{\mu_{0} I}{2 \pi r}+\frac{2 \mu_{0} I}{6 \pi r}=\frac{5 \mu_{0} I}{6 \pi r} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 33 Radiation resistance of a small dipole current element of length l at a frequency of 3 GHz is 3 ohms. If the length is changed by 1%, then the percentage change in the radiation resistance, rounded off to two decimal places, is _____ %.
solution: Radiation resistance of a small dipole current  element of length 'I' is [latex] \begin{array}{l} R_{\mathrm{rad}}=80 \pi^{2}\left(\frac{l}{\lambda}\right)^{2} \Rightarrow R \propto l^{2} \\ \frac{R_{2}}{R_{1}}=\left(\frac{l_{2}}{l_{1}}\right)^{2} \end{array}[/latex] If length is changed by 1% then percentage change in the radiation resistance. [latex] \frac{R_{2}}{R_{1}}=\left(\frac{1.01 l}{l}\right)^{2}=1.0201[/latex] [latex] \text { Percentage change in radiation resistance } [/latex] [latex] \begin{array}{l} =\frac{R_{2}-R_{1}}{R_{1}} \times 100 \\ =0.0201 \times 100=2.01 \% \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 35 What is the electric flux ([latex]\int \vec{E}\cdot d\hat{a}[/latex]) through a quarter-cylinder of height H (as shown in the figure) due to an infinitely long line charge along the axis of the cylinder with a charge density of Q?
solution: Electric field intensity [latex](\vec{E})[/latex] at '[latex]\rho[/latex]' distance due to infinite long line having line charge density Q is [latex] \begin{aligned} \vec{E} &=\frac{Q}{2 \pi \varepsilon_{0} \rho} \hat{a}_{\rho} \\ \int \vec{E} \cdot \vec{da} &=\iint \frac{Q}{2 \pi \varepsilon_{0} \rho} \hat{a}_{p} \cdot \rho d \phi d z \hat{a}_{\rho} \\ &=\frac{Q}{2 \pi \varepsilon_{0}} \int_{<\pi / 2>} d \phi \int_{z=0}^{H} d z \\ &=\frac{Q}{2 \pi \varepsilon_{0}}\left(\frac{\pi}{2}\right) H=\frac{H Q}{4 \varepsilon_{0}} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 36 A uniform plane wave traveling in free space and having the electric field [latex]\vec{E}=(\sqrt{2}\hat{a}_{x}-\hat{a}_{z})cos[6\sqrt{3}\pi \times 10^{8}t-2\pi (x+\sqrt{2}z)]V/m[/latex] is incident on a dielectric medium (relative permittivity [latex]\gt[/latex]1, relative permeability = 1) as shown in the figure and there is no reflected wave. The relative permittivity (correct to two decimal places) of the dielectric medium is___________.
solution: The wave has [latex]E_{i}[/latex] direction and propagation  direction both in same plane (ZX). The wave is plane of incidence (P) polarized. [latex] \begin{aligned} \beta_{x} &=1, \quad \beta_{2}=\sqrt{2} \\ \tan \theta_{i} &=\frac{\beta_{z}}{\beta_{x}}=\sqrt{2} \end{aligned}[/latex] No reflection in P polarized wave under Brewster's angle of incidence. [latex] \begin{aligned} \theta_{i} &=\theta_{B} \\ \tan \theta_{B} &=\sqrt{2}=\sqrt{\epsilon_{r}} \\ \epsilon_{r} &=2 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 37 The cutoff frequency of [latex] TE_{01} [/latex] mode of an air filled rectangular waveguide having inner
dimensions [latex]a cm \times b cm ( a \gt b)[/latex] is twice that of the dominant [latex] TE_{10}[/latex] mode. When the
waveguide is operated at a frequency which is 25% higher than the cutoff frequency of the
dominant mode, the guide wavelength is found to be 4 cm. The value of b (in cm, correct to
two decimal places) is _______.
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{l} f_{c(01)}=2 f_{c(10)}=\frac{2 c}{2 a}=\frac{c}{a} \\ \frac{c}{2 b}=\frac{c}{a} \Rightarrow a=2 b \Rightarrow b=\frac{a}{2} \end{array}[/latex] Operating frequency, [latex] f=1.25 f_{c(10)}[/latex] [latex] f_{c(10)}\lt 1.25 f_{c(10)} \lt \left[f_{c(01)}=2 f_{c(10)}\right][/latex] So, for the given frequency, the waveguide will work in [latex]\mathrm{TE}_{10}[/latex] mode. [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { So, } \lambda_{g} &=\frac{\lambda_{0}}{\sqrt{1-\left(\frac{f_{c(10)}}{f}\right)^{2}}} \\ &=\frac{c / f}{\sqrt{1-\left(\frac{1}{1.25}\right)^{2}}}=\frac{c / f}{0.6} \\ \frac{c}{(1.25) f_{c(10)}(0.6)} &=\lambda_{g}=4 \mathrm{cm} \\ \frac{c}{f_{c(10)}} &=3 \times 10^{-2}=2 a \\ a &=1.5 \mathrm{cm} \\ b &=\frac{a}{2}=0.75 \mathrm{cm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 38 The distance (in meters) a wave has to propagate in a medium having a skin depth of 0.1 m
so that the amplitude of the wave attenuates by 20 dB, is
solution: Attenuation constant, [latex] \begin{aligned} \alpha &=\frac{1}{\text { skin depth }}=10 \mathrm{Np} / \mathrm{m} \\ \text { 20log }_{10}\left(\frac{E_{0}}{E_{x}}\right) &=20 \mathrm{dB} \\ \frac{E_{o}}{E_{x}} &=10 \Rightarrow E_{x}=\frac{E_{0}}{10} \\ E_{x} &=E_{0} e^{-\alpha x}=E_{0} e^{-10 x}=\frac{E_{0}}{10} \\ e^{-10 x} &=\frac{1}{10} \\ x &=\frac{1}{10} \ln (10)=0.23 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 39 A lossy transmission line has resistance per unit length R = 0.05 [latex]\Omega [/latex] /m. The line is
distortionless and has characteristic impedance of 50 [latex]\Omega [/latex]. The attenuation constant (in Np/m, correct to three decimal places) of the line is _______.
solution: For a distortionless transmission line, [latex] \frac{L}{R}=\frac{C}{G}[/latex] Propagation constant, [latex] \begin{aligned} \gamma &=\alpha+j \beta=\sqrt{(R+j \omega L)(G+j \omega C)} \\ &=\sqrt{R G}\left(1+j \omega \frac{L}{R}\right) \end{aligned}[/latex] Attenuation constant, [latex] \alpha=\sqrt{R G}[/latex] Characteristic impedance, [latex] \begin{aligned} Z_{0} &=\sqrt{\frac{(R+j \omega L)}{(G+j \omega C)}}=\sqrt{\frac{R}{G}} \\ \sqrt{G} &=\frac{\sqrt{R}}{Z_{0}} \\ \text{So,}\quad\alpha &=\sqrt{R} \cdot \frac{\sqrt{R}}{Z_{0}}=\frac{R}{Z_{0}} \\ &=\frac{0.05}{50}=\frac{0.01}{10}=0.001 \mathrm{Np} / \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 41 Standard air-filled rectangular waveguides of dimensions a = 2.29 cm and b= 1.02 cm are designed for radar applications. It is desired that these waveguides operate only in the dominatnt [latex]TE_{10}[/latex] mode but not higher than 95% of the next higher cutoff frequency. The range of the allowable operating frequency f is.
solution: [latex]a=2.29 \;\mathrm{cm}, b=1.02 \mathrm{cm}[/latex] Waveguide is operating in [latex](TE _{10})[/latex] dominant mode [latex] f_{c}\left(T E_{10}\right)=\frac{c}{2 a}=\frac{3 \times 10^{10}}{2 \times 2.29}=6.55 \mathrm{GHz}[/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow 25 \% [/latex] above cut-off frequency [latex] =1.25 \times 6.55 \mathrm{GHz}=8.1875 \mathrm{GHz}[/latex] Next higher order mode is [latex]\mathrm{TE}_{20}\left(\because a_{2} \gt 2b\right) [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} f_{c}\left(T E_{20}\right) &=\frac{c}{a}=\frac{3 \times 10^{10}}{2.29}=13.1 \mathrm{GH}_{2} \\ \Rightarrow 95 \% \text { of } f_{c}\left(\mathrm{TE}_{20}\right) &=0.95 \times 13.1 \\ &=12.445 \mathrm{GHz} \end{aligned}[/latex] Range of allowable operating frequency [latex] 8.19 \mathrm{GHz} \leq f \leq 12.45 \mathrm{GHz}[/latex]

question: Question 42 The permittivity of water at optical frequencies is 1.75 [latex]\varepsilon_{0}[/latex]. It is found that an isotropic light source at a distance d under water forms an illuminated circular area of radius 5m, as shown in the figure. The critical angle is [latex]\theta_{c}[/latex]. The value of d (in meter) is _____________
solution: Critical angle, [latex] \begin{aligned} \theta_{c} &=\sin ^{-1} \sqrt{\frac{\epsilon_{2}}{\epsilon_{1}}} \\ &=\sin ^{-1} \sqrt{\frac{\epsilon_{0}}{1.75 \epsilon_{0}}}=49.1^{\circ} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \tan 49.1 &=1.547=\frac{5}{d} \\ \Rightarrow \quad d &=\frac{5}{1.1547}=4.33 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 43 An electron ([latex]q_1[/latex]) is moving in free space with velocity [latex]10^{5}[/latex] m/s towards a stationary electron ([latex]q_2[/latex]) far away. The closest distance that this moving electron gets to the stationary electron before the repulsive force diverts its path is ___________ [latex]\times 10^{-8}[/latex]m. [Given, mass of electron [latex]m=9.11 \times 10^{-31}[/latex] kg, charge of electron [latex]e=-1.6 \times 10^{-19}[/latex]C, and permittivity [latex] \varepsilon_{0}=(1/36\pi)\times 10^{-9}F/m][/latex]
solution: r is the distance at which kinetic energy of [latex]q_{1}[/latex] becomes zero [(because kinetic energy (KE) is converted into potential energy (PE)]. When [latex]q_{1}[/latex] reaches 'r', it starts diverting. Kinetic energy, [latex]K E=\frac{1}{2} m v^{2}[/latex] and work done in moving [latex]q_{1}[/latex] charge to distance 'r' is [latex] \begin{aligned} q_{1} v_{2}&=q_{1} \frac{q_{2}}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0} r} \\ &\qquad\left(q_{1}=q_{2}=-1.6 \times 10^{-19} \mathrm{C}\right)\\ Now, \quad \frac{1}{2} m v^{2}&=\frac{q_{1} q_{2}}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0} r} \\ \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow r=\frac{\left(2 \times-1.6 \times 10^{-19}\right) \times\left(-1.6 \times 10^{-19}\right)}{4 \pi \times \frac{10^{-9}}{36 \pi} \times 9.11 \times 10^{-31} \times\left(10^{5}\right)^{2}}[/latex] [latex] \simeq 5.06 \times 10^{-8} \mathrm{m}[/latex]

question: Question 44 A two - wire transmission line terminates in a television set. The VSWR measured on the line is 5.8. The percentage of power that is reflected from the television set is ______________
solution: Given that, VSWR (or) [latex]s=5.8 [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} s &=\frac{1+|\Gamma|}{1-|\Gamma|}=5.8 \\ \Gamma &=\text { Reflection coefficient of } \\ &\quad \text { television set } \\ \Gamma &=\frac{s-1}{s+1}=\frac{4.8}{6.8}=0.70588 \\ \frac{P_{\text {reflected }}}{P_{\text {incident }}} &=\Gamma^{2}=0.4983 \text { or } 49.83 \% \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 45 Two conducting spheres S1 and S2 of radii a and b (b>a) respectively, are placed far apart and connected by a long, thin conducting wire, as shown in the figure. For some charge placed on this structure, the potential and surface electric field on S1 are [latex]V_{a}[/latex] and [latex] E_{a}[/latex], and that on S2 are [latex]V_{b}[/latex] and [latex]E_{b}[/latex], respectively, which of the following is CORRECT?
solution: When charge is placed on this structure equilibrium is established such that be  spheres are at same potential i.e. [latex] V_{a}=V_{b}[/latex] [latex] \begin{array}{c} V_{a}=V_{b} \\ \text { So, } \frac{Q_{a}}{4 \pi \epsilon_{o} a}=\frac{Q_{b}}{4 \pi \epsilon_{o} b} \end{array}[/latex] [latex] \frac{Q_{b}}{Q_{a}}=\frac{b}{a}[/latex] Now, surface electric fields. [latex] \frac{E_{a}}{E_{b}}=\left[\frac{Q_{a} / 4 \pi \varepsilon_{o} a^{2}}{Q_{b} / 4 \pi \varepsilon_{o} b^{2}}\right]=\frac{Q_{a} \times b^{2}}{Q_{b} \times a^{2}}=\frac{b}{a}>1[/latex] [latex] So, E_{a}>E_{b}[/latex]

question:
Question 47 The expression for an electric field in free space is [latex]E=E_{0}=(\hat{x}+\hat{y}+j2\hat{z})e^{-j(\omega t-kx+ky)}[/latex], where  x, y,
z represent the spatial coordinates, t represents time, and [latex] \omega[/latex], k are constants. This electric field
solution: [latex]\vec{E} [/latex] field direction [latex]\Rightarrow\left(\hat{a}_{x}+\hat{a}_{y}+j 2 \hat{a}_{z}\right)[/latex] Propagation direction [latex]\Rightarrow k \hat{a}_{x}-k \hat{a}_{y} [/latex] [latex] \vec{E} [/latex] is perpendicular to propagation [latex] \vec{E} \cdot \vec{P}=0[/latex] Component in [latex]\hat{a}_{z}[/latex] has magnitude of 2. Component in X-Y plane has magnitude of [latex]\sqrt{2}.[/latex] These two components are out of phase by [latex]90^{\circ} [/latex] and have unequal amplitudes. question: Question 48 An optical fiber is kept along the [latex]\hat{z}[/latex] direction. The refractive indices for the electric fields along [latex]\hat{x}[/latex] and [latex]\hat{y}[/latex] directions in the fiber are [latex]n_{x}[/latex]=1.5000 and [latex]n_{y}[/latex]=1.5001, respectively ([latex]n_{x} \neq n_{y}[/latex] due to the imperfection in the fiber cross-section). The free space wavelength of a light wave propagating in the fiber is 1.5[latex]\mu[/latex]m. If the light wave is circularly polarized at the input of the fiber, the minimum propagation distance after which it becomes linearly polarized, in centimeter, is ___________.
solution:
Initially the wave is circularly polarized. So, the 
initial phase difference between field components 
in [latex] \hat{a}_{x} [/latex] direction and [latex] \hat{a}_{y} [/latex] direction is [latex] \frac{\pi}{2} [/latex] To become linearly polarized, the wave must travel 
a minimum distance, such that, the phase 
difference at that point between the field 
components in [latex] \hat{a}_{x} [/latex] direction and [latex] \hat{a}_{y} [/latex] direction is [latex] \pi [/latex] (i.e., the travel of this minimum distance should 
provide an additional phase difference of [latex] \pi / 2 [/latex] 
between [latex] \hat{a}_{x} [/latex] and [latex] \hat{a}_{y} [/latex] field components). So, [latex]\begin{aligned} z_{min}k_z&\sim z_{min}k_y=\frac{\pi}{2} \\ z_{min}\left [ \frac{\omega }{V_{px}}\sim \frac{\omega }{V_{py}} \right ]&= \frac{\pi}{2} \\ 2 \pi z_{min}\left [ \frac{f}{c}\sqrt{\varepsilon _{rx}}\sim \frac{f}{c}\sqrt{\varepsilon _{ry}}\right ]&=\frac{\pi}{2} \\ \frac{4 z_{min}}{\lambda _0}[n_x\sim n_y]&=1 \\ z_{min}&=\frac{\lambda _0}{4(n_x\sim n_y)} \\ &=\frac{1.5}{4(1.5\sim 1.5001)}\mu m \\ &= \frac{1.5}{4(0.0001)}\mu m=\frac{1.5}{4}cm\\ z_{min}&=0.375cm \end{aligned}[/latex]

unchanged, the maximum capacity of the wireless link

Question 50 The voltage of an electromagnetic wave propagating in a coaxial cable with uniform characteristic impedance is [latex]V(\iota )=e^{-y \iota +j\omega t}[/latex] volts, Where [latex]\iota [/latex] is the distance along the length of the cable in meters.  [latex] \gamma =(0.1+j40)m^{-1} [/latex] is the complex propagation constant, and [latex] \omega = 2\pi \times 10^{9} rad/ s[/latex]  is the angular frequency. The absolute value of the attenuation in the cable in dB/meter is __________.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} V(l) &=V_{O} e^{-\alpha l} e^{-j\beta l} e^{j\omega t} \\ \text { Attenuation } &=\frac{\mid \text { Input } \mid}{\mid \text { Output } \mid}=\frac{\left|V_{O}(0)\right|}{\left|V_{o}(l)\right|} \end{aligned}[/latex] Attenuation per meter [latex]=\frac{\left|V_{0}\right|}{\left|V_{0}(1 \mathrm{m})\right|}=e^{\alpha} [/latex] Attenuation in [latex]\mathrm{dB} / \mathrm{m}=\left(20 \log e^{\alpha}\right) \mathrm{dB} / \mathrm{m} [/latex] [latex] =20(0.1) \log e=0.868 \mathrm{dB} / \mathrm{m}[/latex]

question: Question 51 Consider the charge profile shown in the figure. The resultant potential distribution is best described by
solution: Applying Poisson's equations [latex] \nabla^{2} V=\frac{\partial^{2} V}{\partial x^{2}}=-\frac{\rho_{v}}{\epsilon}=K[/latex] Constant charge density [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{\partial V}{\partial x} &=-K x+K^{\prime} \\ V &=\frac{-K x^{2}}{2}+K^{\prime} x+K^{\prime} \end{aligned}[/latex] Towards positive x or negative side. It is a second order parabolic increase. Due to symmetry of + and - charges K" = 0 is expected with V = O at centre and graph passing through origin. Beyond [latex]x \gt 0 \text{ or } x \lt  b, \; E = 0[/latex] due to capacitive nature of + and - charges [latex] V=-\int 0 \cdot \overrightarrow{d l}=\text { Constant }[/latex] This  constant is same V at x=a or x=b

question: Question 52 A radar operating at 5 GHz uses a common antenna for transmission and reception. The antenna has a gain of 150 and is aligned for maximum directional radiation and reception to a target 1 km away having radar cross-section of 3 [latex]m^{2}[/latex]. If it transmits 100 kW, then the received power (in [latex]\mu[/latex]W) is__________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} f&=5 \mathrm{GHz}, G=150, R=1 \mathrm{km} \\ P_{t}&=100 \mathrm{kW}, \sigma=3 \mathrm{m}^{2} \\ P_{r}&= \frac{(G \lambda)^{2} \cdot \sigma}{(4 \pi)^{3} R^{4}} \times P_{t} \\ &=\frac{\left(150 \times \frac{3 \times 10^{8}}{5 \times 10^{9}}\right)^{2} \cdot 3}{(4 \pi)^{3} \cdot 10^{12}} \times 10^{5} \\ &=\frac{81 \times 3 \times 10^{5}}{(4 \pi)^{3} \times 10^{12}} \\ &= 1.224 \times 10^{-8}=0.012 \mu \mathrm{W} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 53 Consider an air-filled rectangular waveguide with dimensions a = 2.286 cm and b = 1.016 cm. The increasing order of the cut-off frequencies for different modes is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} a &=2.286 \mathrm{cm} \\ b &=1.016 \mathrm{cm} \\ f_{c_{T E_{10}}} &=\frac{c}{2 a} \\ f_{c_{T E_{01}}} &=\frac{c}{2 b} \\ f_{c_{T E_{20}}} &=\frac{c}{a} \\ f_{c_{T E_{11}}} &=\frac{c}{2} \sqrt{\left(\frac{1}{a}\right)^{2}+\left(\frac{1}{b}\right)^{2}} \\ \text{As }a \gt 2 b \Rightarrow f_{c_{T E_{10}}} & \lt f_{c_{T E_{20}}} \lt f_{c_{T E_{01}}} \lt f_{c_{T E_{11}}} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 54 Consider an air-filled rectangular waveguide with dimensions a = 2.286 cm and b = 1.016 cm. At 10 GHz operating frequency, the value of the propagation constant (per meter) of the corresponding propagating mode is __________
solution: Operation frequency [latex]=10 \mathrm{GHz}[/latex] Cut off frequency for [latex]\mathrm{TE}_{10}, \mathrm{f}_{c}=\frac{\mathrm{c}}{2 \mathrm{a}} [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} f_{c} &=\frac{3 \times 10^{8}}{2 \times 2.286 \times 10^{-2}} \\ &=6.57 \mathrm{GHz} \end{aligned}[/latex] Next mode [latex]T E_{20}[/latex] has [latex]f_{c}=13 \mathrm{GHz} [/latex] [latex] 10 \mathrm{GHz} [/latex] operates only in dominant mode. [latex] \begin{aligned} r &=\sqrt{\left(\frac{m \pi}{a}\right)^{2}-\omega^{2} \mu \epsilon} \\ &=\sqrt{\left(\frac{\pi}{a}\right)^{2}-\frac{(2 \pi f)^{2}}{\left(3 \times 10^{8}\right)^{2}}} \\ &=\pi \sqrt{\left(\frac{1}{2.286 \times 10^{-2}}\right)^{2}-\left(\frac{2 \times 10 \times 10^{9}}{3 \times 10^{8}}\right)^{2}} \\ &=j 158\left(\mathrm{m}^{-1}\right) \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 55 Faraday's law of electromagnetic induction is mathematically described by which one of the following equations?
solution: Rate of change of magnetic field results in induced voltage, [latex] \nabla \times \vec{E}=-\frac{\partial \vec{B}}{\partial t}[/latex]

question: Question 56 If a right-handed circularly polarized wave is incident normally on a plane perfect conductor, then the reflected wave will be
solution:
Left circularly polarized, due to direction change
after the reflection from conductor.

options.C: elliptically polarized with a tilt angle of [latex]45^{\circ}[/latex]

question:
Question 57 A positive charge q is placed at x= 0 between two infinite metal plates placed at x =-d and at x = +d respectively. The metal plates lie in the yz plane. The charge is at rest at t = 0, when a voltage +V is applied to the plate at -d and voltage -V is
applied to the plate at x=+d . Assume that the quantity of the charge q is small enough that it does not perturb the field set up by the metal plates. The time that the charge q takes to reach the right plate is proportional to
solution: Velocity being free velocity, [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{1}{2} m v^{2} &=q V \\ v &=\frac{d}{t}=\sqrt{\frac{2 q V}{m}} \\ \Rightarrow t \propto \frac{d}{\sqrt{V}} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 58 A microwave circuit consisting of lossless transmission lines [latex]T_{1} \; and \;  T_{2}[/latex] is shown in the figure. The plot shows the magnitude of the input reflection coefficient  [latex]\tau[/latex] as a function of frequency f. The phase velocity of the signal in the transmission lines is [latex]2*10^{8} m/s[/latex]. The length L (in meters) of [latex]T_2[/latex] is _______
solution: At frequency of [latex]1 \mathrm{GHz}[/latex] the line is matched and [latex] | \Gamma |=0 [/latex] as seen in the graph. The line [latex]T_{1}[/latex] is having [latex]50 \Omega[/latex] load parallel to [latex]T_{2}[/latex] input impedance. This load is [latex]50\Omega[/latex] when [latex]T_{2}[/latex] input impedance is infinite. [latex] \begin{aligned} Z_{\text {in } 2}&=\infty=Z_{L 2} \text{ (open circuit) }\\ T_{2}\text{ has to be a }\frac{\lambda}{2}\text{ line}.&\\ f &=1 \mathrm{GHz} \\ \lambda &=\frac{2 \times 10^{10}}{1 \times 10^{9}} \mathrm{cm} \\ \frac{\lambda}{2} &=L=10 \mathrm{cm}=0.1 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 59 A lossless microstrip transmission line consists of a trace of width w. It is drawn over a practically infinite ground plane and is separated by a dielectric slab of thickness t and relative permittivity [latex]\varepsilon _{r} \gt 1[/latex].  The inductance per unit length and the characteristic impedance of this line are L and [latex]Z_{0}[/latex], respectively. Which one of the following inequalities is always satisfied?

Question 60 The parallel-plate capacitor shown in the figure has movable plates. The capacitor is charged so that the energy stored in it is E when the plate separation is d. The capacitor is then isolated electrically and the plates are moved such that the plate separation becomes 2d. At this new plate separation, what is the energy stored in the capacitor, neglecting fringing effects?
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{l} \text { Let, } E=E_{1} \text { , Energy } E_{1}=\frac{Q_{1}^{2}}{2 C_{1}} \\ \text { Electrically isolated } \Rightarrow Q_{2}=Q_{1} \\ \begin{aligned} d_{2}=2 d_{1} \Rightarrow \;& C_{2}=\frac{C_{1}}{2} \\ E_{2} &=\frac{Q_{2}^{2}}{2 C_{2}}=\frac{Q_{1}^{2}}{\frac{2 C_{1}}{2}}=2\left(\frac{Q_{1}^{2}}{2 C_{1}}\right) \\ &=2 E_{1}=2 E \end{aligned} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 61 Light from free space is incident at an angle [latex]\theta _{i}[/latex]  to the normal of the facet of a step-index large core optical fibre. The core and cladding refractive indices are [latex]n _{1}=1.5 \; and \; n_{2}=1.4[/latex], respectively. The maximum value of [latex]\theta _{i}[/latex] (in degrees) for which the incident light will be guided in the core of the fibre is ________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} & \sin \alpha_{\max } &=\sqrt{n_{1}^{2}-n_{2}^{2}}=\sqrt{1.5^{2}-1.4^{2}} \\ \Rightarrow & \alpha_{\max } &=\sin ^{-1}(0.5385)=32.58^{\circ} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 62 Let the electric field vector of a plane electromagnetic wave propagating in a homogenous medium be expressed as [latex]E=\hat{x}E_{x}e^{-j(\omega t-\beta z)}[/latex], where the propagation constant [latex]\beta[/latex] is a function of the angular frequency [latex]\omega[/latex]. Assume that [latex]\beta (\omega)[/latex]
 and [latex]E_{x}[/latex] are known and are real. From the information available, which one of the following CANNOT be determined?
solution: [latex]\beta(\omega) [/latex] is known so [latex] V_{g}[/latex] can be calculated. [latex] v_{p}=\omega / \beta [/latex] can be calculated. Polarization can be identified. [latex] \mu_{r}[/latex] and [latex]\epsilon_{r} [/latex] cannot be found, due to which power flux cannot be calculated as power flux [latex] P=\frac{1}{2} \frac{|E|^{2}}{\eta}, \text{ where }\eta=120 \pi \times \sqrt{\frac{\mu_{r}}{\epsilon_{r}}}[/latex]

options.A: The type of polarization of the wave.
options.B: The group velocity of the wave
options.C: The phase velocity of the wave.
options.D: The power flux through the z = 0 plane.

question: Question 63 A uniform and constant magnetic field [latex]B=\hat{z}B[/latex] exists in the [latex]\hat{z}[/latex] direction in vacuum. A particle of mass m with a small charge q is introduced into this region with an initial velocity [latex]v=\hat{x}v_{x}+\hat{z}v_{z}[/latex]. Given that B, m, q, [latex]v_{x}[/latex] and [latex]v_{z}[/latex] are all non-zero, which one of the following describes the eventual trajectory of the particle?
solution: [latex]\mathrm{Ba}_{\mathrm{z}}[/latex] magnetic field [latex] v_{x} a_{x}+v_{z} a_{z}[/latex] velocity [latex] \begin{aligned} F&=Q(v \times B) \text{ by Lorentz's law}\\ &=Q\left(v_{x} a_{x}+v_{z} a_{z}\right) \times B a_{z} \\ F_{y} &=Q v_{x} \cdot B\left(-a_{y}\right) \end{aligned}[/latex] This results in a circular path in the XY plane with  [latex]v_{z} a_{z}[/latex] component causing a linear path. Both result in a helical path along Z axis.

options.B: Circular motion in the xy plane

question: Question 64 The far-zone power density radiated by a helical antenna is approximated as: [latex]\vec{W}_{rad}=\vec{W}_{average}\approx \hat{a}_{r}C_{o}\frac{1}{r^{2}}cos^{4}\theta[/latex] The radiated power density is symmetrical with respect to [latex]\phi[/latex] and exists only in the upper hemisphere: [latex]0\leq \theta \leq \frac{\pi }{2};0\leq \phi \leq 2\pi;C_{o}[/latex] is a constant. The power radiated by the antenna (in watts) and the maximum directivity of the antenna, respectively, are
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { Power radiated }&=\int P_{\mathrm{rad}} \cdot d s \\ =& \int_{\theta=0}^{\pi / 2} \int_{\theta=0}^{2 \pi} C_{0} \frac{1}{r^{2}} \cos ^{4} \theta \cdot r^{2} \sin \theta d \theta d \phi \\ =& 2 \pi \cdot \frac{C_{0}}{r^{2}} \cdot r^{2} \int_{\theta=0}^{\pi / 2} \cos ^{4} \theta \cdot d(-\cos \theta) \\ =&\left.2 \pi \cdot C_{0}\left(-\frac{\cos ^{5} \theta}{5}\right)\right|_{0} ^{\pi / 2} \\ =& \frac{2 \pi}{5} C_{0}=1.256 C_{0} \\ \text{Directivity}=& \frac{4 \pi \cdot U(\theta, \phi)}{\int(\theta, \phi) \cdot d \Omega} \\ =& \frac{4 \pi \cdot C_{0} \cdot \cos ^{4} \theta}{\int_{\theta=0}^{\pi / 2}\int_{\phi=0}^{2\pi}C_{0} \cdot \cos ^{4} \theta \cdot \sin \theta d \theta d \phi} \\ &=\frac{2 \cos ^{5} \theta}{1 / 5}=10 \cos ^{5} \theta \\ \max _{\operatorname{value}}=& 10 \\ \Rightarrow \max \text { value }(\text { in } \mathrm{dB}) &=10 \log _{10} 10=10 \mathrm{dB} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 65 The electric field of a uniform plane wave travelling along the negative z direction is given by the following equation: [latex]\vec{E}^{1}_{w}=(\hat{a}_{x}+j\hat{a}_{y})E_{0}e^{jkz}[/latex] This wave is incident upon a receiving antenna placed at the origin and whose radiated electric field towards the incident wave is given by the following equation: [latex]\vec{E}_{a}=(\hat{a}_{x}+2\hat{a}_{y})E_{I}\frac{1}{r}e^{-jkr}[/latex] The polarization of the incident wave, the polarization of the antenna and losses due to the polarization mismatch are, respectively,
solution: [latex]\vec{E}_{T}=\left(\hat{a}_{x}+j \hat{a}_{y}\right) E_{0} e^{j k z} [/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow [/latex] Wave contains two orthogonal components and  Y component leads X component leads by [latex]90^{\circ} [/latex] and also wave is travelling in negative z-direction. [latex] \vec{E}_{R}=\left(\hat{a}_{x}+2 \hat{a}_{y}\right) E_{1} \frac{1}{r} e^{-j k r} [/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow [/latex] Wave contains two orthogonal components  with unequal amplitudes and both are in-phase. [latex] \Rightarrow [/latex] Linear polarization. Polarization Loss Factor, [latex] \mathrm{PLF}=\left|\hat{E}_{T} \cdot \hat{E}_{R}\right|^{2} [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} Where, E_{T}&=\frac{\hat{a}_{x}+j \hat{a}_{y}}{\sqrt{2}} \\ E_{R}&=\frac{\hat{a}_{x}+2 \hat{a}_{y}}{\sqrt{5}} \\ P L&= \left|\frac{1+j 2^{2}}{\sqrt{10} }\right|=\frac{5}{10}=\frac{1}{2} \\ \Rightarrow \quad P L F(d B)&=10 \log \frac{1}{2}=-3 \mathrm{dB} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 66 Two lossless X-band horn antennas are separated by a distance of 200[latex]\lambda[/latex]. The amplitude reflection coefficients at the terminals of the transmitting and receiving antennas are 0.15 and 0.18, respectively. The maximum directivities of the transmitting and receiving antennas (over the isotropic antenna) are 18 dB and 22 dB, respectively. Assuming that the input power in the lossless transmission line connected to the antenna is 2 W, and that the antennas are perfectly aligned and
polarization matched, the power ( in mW) delivered to the load at the receiver is ________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} G_{t}&=10^{1.8}, G_{r}=10^{2.2} \\ P_{r}&=\frac{\left(1-\left|\Gamma_{t}\right|^{2}\right)\left(1-\left|\Gamma_{r}\right|^{2}\right) G_{t} G_{r}}{\left(\frac{4 \pi d}{\lambda}\right)^{2}} \cdot P_{t}\\ &=\frac{\left(1-|0.15|^{2}\right)\left(1-|0.18|^{2}\right) 10^{1.8} \cdot 10^{2.2}}{\left(\frac{4 \pi 200 \lambda}{\lambda}\right)^{2}} \times 2 \\ &=2.99476 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{W}=2.995 \mathrm{mW} \approx 3 \mathrm{mW} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 67 The current density in a medium is given by [latex]\vec{j}=\frac{400 sin\theta }{2\pi (r^{2})+4}\hat{a}_{r}Am^{-2}[/latex] The total current and the average current density flowing through the portion of a spherical surface r = 0.8 m, [latex]\frac{\pi }{12}\leq \theta \leq \frac{\pi }{4},0\leq \phi \leq 2\pi[/latex] are given, respectively, by
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} I &=\int \overrightarrow{J} \cdot \overrightarrow{d s} \\ &=\int_{\theta=\frac{\pi}{12}}^{\pi / 4} \int_{\phi=0}^{2 \pi} \frac{400 \sin \theta}{2 \pi\left(r^{2}+4\right)} r^{2} \sin \theta d \theta d \phi \\ &=\left.\frac{400}{2 \pi\left(r^{2}+4\right)} \cdot r^{2} \cdot \phi\right|_{0} ^{2 \pi} \int_{\pi / 12}^{\pi / 4} \sin ^{2} \theta d \theta \\ &=\frac{400 r^{2}}{\left(r^{2}+4\right)} \int_{\pi / 12}^{\pi / 4}\left(\frac{1-\cos 2 \theta}{2}\right) d \theta \\ &=\frac{400 \cdot r^{2}}{\left(r^{2}+4\right)}\left(\frac{\left(\frac{\pi}{4}-\frac{\pi}{12}\right)}{2}-\left(\frac{\sin 2 \theta}{4}\right)_{\pi / 12}^{\pi / 4}\right) \\ &=\left.\frac{400 \cdot r^{2}}{\left(r^{2}+4\right)}\left(\frac{\pi}{12}-\left(\frac{1-1 / 2}{4}\right)\right)\right|_{r=0.8} \\ &=\frac{400 \times 0.8 \times 0.8}{4.64} \times 0.13=7.17 \mathrm{Amp} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]\begin{array}{l} \text { Total area }=\int d s=\iint r^{2} \sin \theta d \theta d \phi \\ =r^{2} \int_{0=\frac{\pi}{12}}^{\pi / 4} \sin \theta d \theta \cdot 2 \pi \\ =\left.r^{2} \cdot 2 \pi \cdot 0.259\right|_{r=0.8} \\ =0.8^{2} \times 0.5 \times 2 \pi \times \frac{1}{4} \\ =1.041 \mathrm{m}^{2} \\ \text { Average current }=\frac{7.17}{1.041}=6.88 \mathrm{A} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \end{array}[/latex] Note : GATE key mentioned (MTA - marks to all)

question:
Question 68 The propagation constant of a lossy transmission line is [latex] (2 +j5) m^{-1}[/latex]
 and its characteristic impedance is [latex](50 + j0) \Omega[/latex] at [latex]\omega = 10^{6}[/latex] rad [latex]s^{-1}[/latex]. The values of the line constants L, C,R, G are, respectively,
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \gamma &=\sqrt{(R+j \omega L)(G+j \omega C)} \\ Z_{0} &=\sqrt{\frac{R+j \omega L}{G+j \omega C}} \\ \gamma \cdot Z_{0}=R+j \omega L =&(2+j 5)(50+j 0)=100+j 250 \\ R &=100 \Omega / m \\ L &=\frac{250}{\omega}=\frac{250}{10^{6}}=250 \mu \mathrm{H} / \mathrm{m} \\ \frac{\gamma}{Z_{0}}=\frac{2+j 5}{50}=G &+\dot{j \omega C}=0.04+j 0.1 \\ G &=0.04 \mathrm{S} / \mathrm{m} \\ C &=\frac{0.1}{\omega}=\frac{0.1}{10^{6}}=0.1 \mu \mathrm{F} / \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

options.D: [latex]L=250\mu H/m, C=0.2 \mu F/m,[/latex] [latex] R=50\Omega /m, G=0.04 S/m[/latex]

question:
Question 69 Concentric spherical shells of radii 2 m, 4 m, and 8 m carry uniform surface charge densities of 20 nC/[latex]m^{2}[/latex], -4 nC/[latex]m^{2}[/latex] and [latex]\rho _{s}[/latex] , respectively. The value of [latex]\rho _{s}  (nC/m^{2})[/latex] required to ensure that the
electric flux density [latex]\overrightarrow{D}=\overrightarrow{0}[/latex]at radius 10 m is _________
solution: [latex]\oint \vec{D} \cdot ds=Q \quad [/latex] (charge enclosed) [latex] Q_{1}+Q_{2}+Q_{3}=0 [/latex] For D=0 [latex] \rho_{s 1} \cdot 4 \pi 2^{2}+\rho_{s 2} \cdot 4 \pi \cdot 4^{2}+\rho_{s 3} \cdot 4 \pi \cdot 8^{2}=Q=0 [/latex] [latex] 20 \cdot 4-4.4^{2}+\rho_{s 3} \cdot 8^{2}=0 [/latex] [latex] 80-64+\rho_{s 3} \cdot 8^{2}=0 [/latex] [latex] \rho_{s 3}=\frac{-16}{64}=-0.25 \mathrm{nC} / \mathrm{m}^{2}[/latex]

question: Question 70 A coaxial capacitor of inner radius 1 mm and outer radius 5 mm has a capacitance per unit length of 172 pF/m. If the ratio of outer radius to inner radius is doubled, the capacitance per unit length (in pF/m) is ________.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} C &=\frac{2 \pi \in}{ln \frac{b}{a}} \\ 172 \times 10^{-12} &=\frac{2 \pi \epsilon}{ln 5} \\ & \in \frac{172 \times 10^{-12} \times ln 5}{2 \pi} \end{aligned}[/latex] If ratio of [latex]\frac{b}{a} [/latex] is doubled then [latex] \begin{array}{l} C=\frac{2 \pi \epsilon}{\ln 10}=\frac{2 \pi \times \frac{172 \times 10^{-12} \times \ln 5}{2 \pi}}{\ln 10} \\ C=120.22 \mathrm{pF} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 71 A 200 m long transmission line having parameters shown in the figure is terminated into a load [latex]R_{L}[/latex]. The line is connected to a 400 V source having source resistance [latex]R_{S}[/latex] through a switch, which is closed at t = 0. The transient response of the circuit at the input of the line (z = 0) is also drawn in the figure. The value of [latex]R_{L}[/latex] (in [latex] \Omega [/latex]) is ________.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { At } t&=0 \\ &V_{\text {in }}=400 \times \frac{R_{0}}{R_{0}+R_{s}}=400 \times \frac{50}{200}=100 V \\ \text { At } t&=T_{0} \Gamma_{L} 100 \text { volts reflects }\\ \text { At } t&=2T_{0}\\ V_{\text {in }} &=100+\left(1+\Gamma_{\text {in }}\right) \Gamma_{L} 100=62.5 \\ \Gamma_{\text {in }} &=\frac{R_{s}-R_{o}}{R_{s}+R_{o}}=\frac{1}{2} \\ \text { Therefore, } \Gamma_{L} &=-\frac{1}{4}=\frac{R_{L}-50}{R_{L}+50} \\ R_{L} &=30 \Omega \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 72 Consider the 3 m long lossless air-filled transmission line shown in the figure. It has a characteristic impedance of 120[latex]\pi \Omega[/latex], is terminated by a short circuit, and is excited with a frequency of 37.5 MHz. What is the nature of the input impedance ([latex]Z_{in}[/latex])?
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} l &=3 \mathrm{m} \\ f &=37.5 \mathrm{MHz} \\ \Rightarrow \quad \lambda &=\frac{3 \times 10^{8}}{37.5 \times 10^{6}}=8 \mathrm{m} \\ Z_{\text {in }}(S C) &=j Z_{0} \tan \beta l=j 120 \pi \tan \frac{2 \pi}{8} \cdot 3 \\ &=-j 120 \pi \Omega \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 73 A vector field [latex]D=2\rho ^{2} a_{\rho }+z a_{z}[/latex] exists inside a cylindrical region enclosed by the surfaces [latex]\rho[/latex]= 1, z = 0 and z = 5. Let S be the surface bounding this cylindrical region. The surface integral of this field on [latex]S(\oint\oint_{S} D.ds)[/latex]  is _______.
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{c} \vec{D}=2 \rho^{2} \hat{a}_{p}+z \hat{a}_{z} \\ \text { surface: } \rho=1, z=0 \text { and } z=5 \\ \oiint_{s} \vec{D} \cdot ds=\int_{\text {Top surface}} \vec{D} \cdot ds \\ +\int_{\text {Bottom surface}} \vec{D} \cdot ds \\ +\int_{\text {curved surface }} \vec{D} \cdot ds \\ =5 \pi+0+20 \pi=25 \pi=78.54 \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 74 A coaxial cable is made of two brass conductors. The spacing between the conductors is filled with Teflon ( [latex]\varepsilon^{'}_{r}[/latex]= 2.1, tan [latex]\delta[/latex]=0). Which one of the following circuits can represent the lumped element model of a small piece of this cable having length [latex]\Delta[/latex]z?
solution: The teflon dielectric between the lines has [latex] \tan \delta=\text{Loss tangent}=0[/latex] For the medium between the lines [latex] G=0[/latex]

question: Question 75 The directivity of an antenna array can be increased by adding more antenna elements, as a larger number of elements
solution: Directivity (0) is increased by adding more antenna elements in an antenna array. Effective area [latex](A_{e})[/latex] and directivity (D) are related by [latex] A_{e}=\frac{\lambda^{2}}{4 \pi} D [/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow D \uparrow A_{e} \uparrow[/latex]

options.B: increases the effective area of the antenna
options.C: results in a better impedance matching
options.D: allows more power to be transmitted by the antenna

question: Question 76 The electric field of a plane wave propagating in a lossless non-magnetic medium is given by the following expression [latex]E(z,t)=a_{x}5 cos(2\pi \times 10^{9}t+\beta z)+ [/latex] [latex]a_{y} 3 cos(2\pi \times 10^{9}t+\beta z-\pi/2)[/latex] The type of the polarization is
solution: [latex]\vec{E}(z, t)=\hat{a}_{x} 5 \cos \left(2 \pi \times 10^{9} t+\beta z\right) [/latex] [latex] +\hat{a}_{y} 3 \cos \left(2 \pi \times 10^{9} t+\beta z-\frac{\pi}{2}\right) [/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow [/latex] Wave is travelling in [latex]-\hat{a}_{z}[/latex] direction. [latex] \Rightarrow [/latex] Wave has orthogonal components with unequal amplitudes and checking the time trace. [latex] \therefore[/latex] Wave is left hand elliptically polarized.

question: Question 77 Two half-wave dipole antennas placed as shown in the figure are excited with sinusoidally varying currents of frequency 3 MHz and phase shift of [latex]\pi/2[/latex] between them(the element at the origin leads in phase). If the maximum radiated E-field at the point P in the x-y plane occurs at an azimuthal angle of [latex]60^{\circ}[/latex], the distance d (in meters) between the antennas is _________.
solution: Both dipole antennas have isotropic pattern in [latex]\phi [/latex] view or H plane view. [latex] \psi=\beta d \cos \theta+\alpha[/latex] where, [latex]\alpha=-90^{\circ}, \beta=\frac{2 \pi}{\lambda}=\frac{2 \pi}{\frac{3 \times 10^{8}}{3 \times 10^{6}}}=\frac{2 \pi}{100} [/latex] Since maximum radiation [latex](\psi=0)[/latex] is at [latex]\theta=60^{\circ} [/latex] [latex] \begin{array}{l} \Rightarrow \quad 0=\frac{2 \pi}{100} d \cos 60^{\circ}-90^{\circ} \\ \Rightarrow \quad 90=\frac{360}{100} d \frac{1}{2} \\ \Rightarrow \quad d=50 \mathrm{m} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 78 An air-filled rectangular waveguide of internal dimensions [latex]a \; cm \times b \;  cm \; (a \gt b)[/latex] has a cutoff frequency of 6 GHz for the dominant [latex]TE_{10}[/latex] mode. For the same waveguide, if the cutoff frequencyof the [latex] TM_{11}[/latex] mode is 15 GHz, the cutoff frequency of the [latex]TE_{01}[/latex] mode in GHz is __________.
solution: Given, [latex]f_{c} T E_{10}[/latex] mode is [latex]6 \mathrm{GHz} [/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow \quad \frac{c}{2 a}=\frac{3 \times 10^{10}}{2 \times a}=6 \times 10^{9} [/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow a=2.5 \mathrm{cm} [/latex] Given [latex]f_{c}[/latex] for [latex]T M_{11}[/latex] mode is [latex]15 \mathrm{GHz} [/latex] [latex] \begin{array}{l} \Rightarrow \frac{c}{2} \sqrt{\frac{1}{a^{2}}+\frac{1}{b^{2}}}=15 \times 10^{9} \\ \begin{array}{l} \frac{3 \times 10^{10}}{2} \sqrt{\frac{1}{6.25}+\frac{1}{b^{2}}}=15 \times 10^{9} \\ \Rightarrow \quad b=\frac{2.5}{\sqrt{5.25}} \end{array} \\ \begin{aligned} \Rightarrow \quad & \quad 2 \end{aligned} \end{array}[/latex] Now [latex]f_{c}[/latex] for [latex]T E_{01}[/latex] mode is, [latex] \begin{aligned} f_{c} &=\frac{c}{2 b}=\frac{3 \times 10^{10}}{2.5} \sqrt{5.25} \\ &=13.75 \mathrm{GHz} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 79 The electric field of a uniform plane electromagnetic wave is [latex]\vec{E}=(\vec{a}_{x}+j4\vec{a}_{y})exp[j(2\pi \times 10^{7}t-0.2z)][/latex] The polarization of the wave is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \vec{E}(z, t)=& \hat{a}_{x} 5 \cos \left(2 \pi \times 10^{9} t+\beta z\right) \\ &+\hat{a}_{y} 3 \cos \left(2 \pi \times 10^{9} t+\beta z-\frac{\pi}{2}\right) \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow [/latex] Wave is travelling in [latex]-\hat{a}_{z}[/latex] direction. [latex] \Rightarrow [/latex] Wave has orthogonal components with unequal  amplitudes and checking the time trace. [latex] \therefore [/latex] Wave is left hand elliptically polarized.

question: Question 80 In a source free region in vacuum, if the electrostatic potential [latex]\varphi = 2x^{2}+y^{2}+cz^{2}[/latex], the value of constant c must be _______.
solution:

question: Question 81 Consider a uniform plane wave with amplitude [latex](E_{0})[/latex] of 10 V/m and 1.1 GHz frequency travelling in air, and incident normally on a dielectric medium with complex relative permittivity ([latex]\varepsilon_{r}[/latex]) and permeability ([latex]\mu_{r}[/latex]) as shown in the figure. The magnitude of the transmitted electric field component (in V/m) after it has travelled a distance of 10 cm inside the dielectric region is_________.
solution: Material has [latex]\mu_{R}[/latex] and [latex]\epsilon_{R}[/latex] complex. [latex] \eta \text { of material }=\sqrt{\frac{j \omega \mu}{\sigma+j \omega \epsilon}}=\sqrt{\frac{\mu_{o} \mu_{R}}{\epsilon_{o} \epsilon_{R}}}=120 \pi[/latex] where, [latex]\sigma=0 \quad[/latex] (dielectric) No reflections at the boundary. [latex] \begin{aligned} \gamma &=\text { Propagation constant } \\ &=\sqrt{j \omega \mu_{o} \mu_{R}\left(0+j \omega \epsilon_{o} \epsilon_{R}\right)} \\ &=\sqrt{j \omega \mu_{o} \epsilon_{o}(1-j 2)} \\ &=j \omega \sqrt{\mu_{o} \epsilon_{o}}+j 2 \omega \sqrt{\mu_{o} \epsilon_{o}} \\ \alpha &=2 \omega \sqrt{\mu_{o} \epsilon_{o}}=4.6 \frac{1}{\mathrm{m}} \\ |E| &=E_{o} e^{-\alpha z} \text { with } Z=0.1 \mathrm{m} \\ |E| &=0.1 \mathrm{V} / \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 82 The electric field intensity of a plane wave traveling in free space is given by the following
expression [latex]E(x,t)=a_{y}24\pi cos(\omega t-k_{0}x)(V/m)[/latex] In this field, consider a square area 10 cm x 10 cm on a plane x + y = 1. The total time-averaged power (in mW) passing through the square area is _______.
solution: [latex]\vec{E}(x, t)=\hat{a}_{y} 24 \pi \cos \left(\omega t-K_{o} x\right) V / m[/latex] Power density [latex] \vec{P}=\frac{1}{2} \frac{|E|^{2}}{\eta}=\frac{1}{2} \frac{(24 \pi)^{2}}{120 \pi} \hat{a}_{x}[/latex] Time-averaged power [latex] \begin{aligned} P_{\mathrm{avg}} &=\vec{P} \cdot \overrightarrow{d s} \\ &=\left[\frac{1}{2} \frac{(24 \pi)^{2}}{120 \pi} \hat{a}_{x}\right] \cdot\left[\frac{\hat{a}_{x}+\hat{a}_{y}}{\sqrt{2}} \times 10^{-2}\right] \\ P_{\mathrm{avg}} &=\frac{24 \pi}{\sqrt{2}}=53.29 \mathrm{mW} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 83 The longitudinal component of the magnetic field inside an air-filled rectangular waveguide made of a perfect electric conductor is given by the following expression [latex]H_{z}(x,y,z,t)=0.1 cos(25\pi x) cos(30.3 \pi y)[/latex] [latex]cos(12 \pi *10^{9}t-\beta z) (A/m)[/latex] The cross-sectional dimensions of the waveguide are given as a = 0.08 m and b = 0.033 m. The
mode of propagation inside the waveguide is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} H_{z}(x, y, z, t) &=0.1 \cos (25 \pi x) \cos (30.3 \pi y) \\ & \cos \left(12 \pi \times 10^{9} t-\beta z\right)^{-1 / m}\\ a &=0.08 m, b=0.033 m \end{aligned}[/latex] Axial component is [latex]\mathrm{H} \Rightarrow[/latex] the propagating mode is [latex] T E_{\text {mn}}[/latex], m, n can be found by [latex] \begin{array}{l} \quad \frac{m \pi}{a} x=25 \pi x \\ \Rightarrow \quad \frac{m}{0.08}=25 \\ \Rightarrow \quad m=2 \\ \Rightarrow \quad \frac{n\pi}{b} y=30.3 \pi y \\ \Rightarrow \quad \frac{n}{0.033}=30.3 \\ \Rightarrow \quad n=1 \end{array}[/latex] [latex] \therefore[/latex] The mode of propagation is [latex]T E_{21}[/latex]

question: Question 84 The electric field component of a plane wave traveling in a lossless dielectric medium is given by [latex]\vec{E}(z,t)=\hat{a_{y}}2cos(10^{8}t-\frac{z}{\sqrt{2}})V/m[/latex]. The wavelength (in m) for the wave is ___________.
solution: [latex]\vec{E}(z, t)=\hat{a}_{y} 2 \cos \left(10^{8} t-\frac{z}{\sqrt{2}}\right) \mathrm{V} / \mathrm{m} [/latex] General form of [latex] \vec{E}(z, t)=\hat{a}_{y} E_{o} \cos (\omega t-\beta z) \vee / m [/latex] Comparing both, we get [latex] \beta=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} [/latex] since, [latex]\beta=\frac{2 \pi}{\lambda} [/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow \quad \lambda=\frac{2 \pi}{\beta}=\frac{2 \pi}{\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}}=2 \sqrt{2} \pi m [/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow \quad \lambda=8.88 \mathrm{m}[/latex]

question: Question 85 Consider a straight, infinitely long, current carrying conductor lying on the z-axis. Which one of the following plots (in linear scale) qualitatively represents the dependence of [latex]H_{\phi}[/latex] on r, where [latex]H_{\phi}[/latex] is the magnitude of the azimuthal component of magnetic field outside the conductor and r is the radial distance from the conductor?
solution: [latex]H_{\phi}=\frac{I}{2 \pi r} \hat{a}_{\phi} [/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow \quad H_{\phi} \propto \frac{1}{r} [/latex]option(c) is satisfied.

question: Question 86 If [latex]\vec{E}=-9(2y^{3}-3yz^{2})\hat{x}-(6xy^{2}-3xz^{2})\hat{y}+(6xyz)\hat{z}[/latex] is the electric field in a source free region, a valid expression for the electrostatic potential is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} E &=-\frac{\partial V}{\partial x} \hat{a}_{x}-\frac{\partial V}{\partial y} \hat{a}_{y}-\frac{\partial V}{\partial Z} \hat{a}_{z} \\ \frac{\partial V}{\partial x} &=2 y^{3}-3 y z^{2} &V=2 x y^{3}-3 x y z^{2}+K_{1} \\ \frac{\partial V}{\partial y} &=6 x y^{2}-3 x z^{2} &V=2 x y^{3}-3 x y z^{2}+K_{2} \\ \frac{\partial V}{\partial z} &=-6 x y z &V=-3 x y z^{2}+K_{3} \end{aligned}[/latex] Comparing all three for uniqueness solution of potential [latex] \begin{array}{c} K_{1}=K_{2}=0, \quad K_{3}=2 x y^{3} \\ \vec{E}=-\left(2 y^{3}-3 y z^{2}\right) \hat{x}-\left(6 x y^{2}-3 x z^{2}\right) \hat{y}+(6 x y z) \hat{z} \end{array}[/latex] as we know that [latex]E=-\nabla V [/latex] [latex] E=-\left(\frac{\partial}{\partial x} \hat{x}+\frac{\partial}{\partial y} \hat{y}+\frac{\partial}{\partial z} \hat{z}\right) V \quad\ldots(i)[/latex] Clearly option (D) satisfies the given relation.

question: Question 87 The electric field (assumed to be one-dimensional) between two points A and B is shown. Let [latex]\psi _{A}[/latex] and [latex]\psi _{B}[/latex] be the electrostatic potentials at A and B, respectively. The value of [latex]\psi _{B}-\psi _{A}[/latex] in Volts is
solution: E is linear from A to B and E=mx+C [latex] \begin{aligned} V&=-\int_{B}^{A}(m x+c) d x \\ \text { At point } A: x&= 0, E=c=2 \times 10^{6} \vee / m =x 10^{-6}\\ \text { At point } B: x &=5 \times 10^{-6} \\ E &=4 \times 10^{6}=m \times 5 \times 10^{-6}+2 \times 10^{6} \\ m &=4 \times 10^{11}\\ -\int^{\Psi_{A}}_{\Psi_{B}} E \cdot d l&=-\int_{5\mu m}^{0}\left[20 \times 10^{5} \times 5 \times 10^{-6}+\frac{4 \times 10^{11}}{2}\left[\left(5 \times 10^{-6}\right)-0^{2}\right]\right] \\ \Psi_{A}-\Psi_{B} &=-\left[\left(20 \times 10^{5} \times 5 \times 10^{-6}\right)+\frac{4 \times 10^{11}}{2}\left[\left(5 \times 10^{-6}\right)^{2}-0^{2}\right]\right] \\ &=-\left[10+\left(2 \times 10^{11} \times 25 \times 10^{-12}\right)\right] \\ &=-15 \mathrm{V} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 89 For an antenna radiating in free space, the electric field at a distance of 1 km is found to be 12mV/m. Given that intrinsic impedance of the free space is [latex]120\pi \Omega[/latex], the magnitude of average power density due to this antenna at a distance of 2 km from the antenna (in nW/[latex]m^{2}[/latex]) is _____.
solution: Given electric field, E at a distance of [latex] 1 \mathrm{km}=12 \mathrm{mV} / \mathrm{m}[/latex] Also we know that [latex]E \propto \frac{1}{r}[/latex], where r is the distance where electric field is to be measured. So, electric field, E at a distance of [latex]2 \mathrm{km} [/latex] [latex] =\frac{12 \mathrm{mV} / \mathrm{m}}{2}=6 \mathrm{mV} / \mathrm{m}[/latex] Also, power density due to the antenna is given as, [latex] \begin{aligned} P_{\text {avg }} &=\frac{1}{2} \frac{E^{2}}{\eta}=\frac{1}{2} \times \frac{6 \times 6 \times 10^{-6}}{120 \pi} \\ &=47.7 \mathrm{nW} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 90 Assume that a plane wave in air with an electric field [latex]\vec{E}=10cos(\omega t-3x-\sqrt{3}z)\hat{a}_{y} V/m[/latex] is incident on a non-magnetic dielectric
slab of relative permittivity 3 which covers the region [latex]z \gt 0[/latex]. The angle of
transmission in the dielectric slab is ____degrees.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \beta_{x}&=3, \beta_{z}=\sqrt{3}\text{ from }E_{i} \text{ of the wave}\\ \theta_{i} &=60^{\circ} \\ \frac{\sin 60^{\circ}}{\sin \theta_{t}} &=\sqrt{3} \\ \theta_{t} &=30^{\circ} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 91 A region shown below contains a perfect conducting half-space and air. The
surface current [latex]\vec{K}_{s}[/latex] on the surface of the perfect conductor is [latex]\hat{K}_{s}=\hat{x}_{2}[/latex] amperes per meter. The tangential [latex]\vec{H}[/latex] field in the air just above the perfect conductor is
solution: since, we know from the property of magnetic boundary conditions i.e. [latex] \vec{H}_{t 2}-\vec{H}_{t 1}=\hat{K}_{s} \times a_{N}[/latex] In the given question the tangential field [latex]\vec{H}[/latex] in the air just above the perfect conductor is asked with H=0 inside the conductor [latex] \begin{array}{l} \vec{H}_{t 1}=0 \\ \vec{H}_{t 2}=\hat{x} 2 \times \hat{y} \\ \vec{H}_{t 2}=\hat{z} 2 \mathrm{A} / \mathrm{m} \end{array}[/latex]

question:
Question 92 In the following figure, the transmitter [latex]T_{X}[/latex]
 sends a wideband modulated RF signal via a coaxial cable to the receiver [latex]R_{X}[/latex]. The output impedance [latex]Z_{T}[/latex] of [latex]T_{X}[/latex],
the characteristic impedance [latex]Z_{0}[/latex] of the cable and the input impedance [latex]Z_{R}[/latex] of [latex]R_{X}[/latex] are all real.
solution:
The signal wave gets distorted if there is any 
impedance mismatch between the characteristic 
impedance [latex] Z_{0} [/latex] and the transmitting impedance [latex] Z_{T} [/latex] 
and [latex] Z_{0} [/latex] and receiving impedance [latex] Z_{R} [/latex] i.e. [latex] Z_{T} \neq Z_{0} [/latex] and [latex] Z_{R} \neq Z_{0} [/latex] then only distortion occurs. As standing waveforms the signal has multi 
harmonics and hence distortion occurs.

options.A: The signal gets distorted if [latex]Z_{R}\neq Z_{0}[/latex], irrespective of the value of [latex]Z_{T}[/latex]
options.B: The signal gets distorted if [latex]Z_{T}\neq Z_{0}[/latex], irrespective of the value of [latex]Z_{R}[/latex]
options.C: Signal distortion implies impedance mismatch at both ends :[latex]Z_{T}\neq Z_{0}[/latex] and [latex]Z_{R}\neq Z_{0}[/latex]
options.D:
Impedance mismatches do NOT result in signal distortion but reduce power
transfer efficiency

question: Question 93 Consider an air filled rectangular waveguide with a cross-section of 5cm x 3cm. For this waveguide, the cut-off frequency (in MHz) of [latex]TE_{21}[/latex] mode is ____.
solution: Given [latex]a=5 \mathrm{cm}=5,10^{-2} \mathrm{m} [/latex] [latex] \begin{array}{c} b=3 \mathrm{cm}=3 \times 10^{-2} \mathrm{m} \\ f_{c}=\frac{C}{2 \pi} \sqrt{\left(\frac{n m}{a}\right)^{2}+\left(\frac{r m}{b}\right)^{2}} \\ f_{C T E_{21}}=\frac{C}{2} \sqrt{\left(\frac{2}{5 \mathrm{cm}}\right)^{2}+\left(\frac{1}{3 \mathrm{cm}}\right)^{2}} \\ =\frac{3 \times 10^{8}}{2} \sqrt{\left(\frac{2 \times 100}{5}\right)^{2}+\left(\frac{100}{3}\right)^{2}} \\ f_{c}=7810 \mathrm{MHz} \end{array}[/latex]

question:
Question 94 For a rectangular waveguide of internal dimensions [latex]a \times b(a \gt b)[/latex], the cur-off
frequency for the [latex]TE_{11}[/latex] mode is the arithmetic mean of the cut-off frequencies for [latex]TE_{10}[/latex] mode and [latex]TE_{20}[/latex] mode. If a = [latex]\sqrt{5}[/latex] cm, the value of b (in cm) is______.
solution: Cut-off frequency of a rectangular waveguide is [latex] \begin{aligned} f_{c}&=\frac{c}{2 \pi} \sqrt{\left(\frac{m \pi}{a}\right)^{2}+\left(\frac{n\pi}{b}\right)^{2}} \\ f_{c} \text{ for }\quad T E_{10}&=\frac{c}{2 \pi} \sqrt{\left(\frac{1 \pi}{a}\right)^{2}}=\frac{c}{2 a} \\ f_{c} \text{ for }\quad T E_{20}&=\frac{c}{2 \pi} \sqrt{\left(\frac{2 \pi}{a}\right)^{2}}=\frac{c}{2 a} \\ f_{c} \text { for } \quad T E_{11} &=\frac{c}{2 \pi} \sqrt{\left(\frac{\pi}{a}\right)^{2}}+\left(\frac{\pi}{b}\right)^{2} \\ &=\frac{c}{2} \sqrt{\left(\frac{1}{a}\right)^{2}+\left(\frac{1}{b}\right)^{2}} \\ \text { Given, } f_{C T_{11}} &=\frac{f_{C_{I E 10}}+f_{C I E_{20}}}{2} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{c}{2} \sqrt{\left(\frac{1}{a}\right)^{2}+\left(\frac{1}{b}\right)^{2}}&=\frac{\frac{c}{2 a}+\frac{c}{a}}{2} \\ \sqrt{\left(\frac{1}{a}\right)^{2}+\left(\frac{1}{b}\right)^{2}}&=\frac{1}{2 a}+\frac{1}{a}=\frac{3}{2 a} \\ \left(\frac{1}{a}\right)^{2}+\left(\frac{1}{b}\right)^{2}&=\frac{9}{4 a^{2}} \\ \Rightarrow \quad\left(\frac{1}{b}\right)^{2} &=\frac{5}{4 a^{2}} \\ b &=\frac{2 a}{\sqrt{5}}=\frac{2 \times \sqrt{5}}{\sqrt{5}} \\ &=2 \mathrm{cm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 95 In the transmission line shown, the impedance [latex]Z_{in}[/latex] (in ohms) between node A and
the ground is _____.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} Z_{\mathrm{in}_{1}} &=Z_{0}\left(\frac{Z_{L}+j Z_{0} \tan \beta l}{Z_{0}+j Z_{L} \tan \beta l}\right) \\ \beta l &=\frac{2 \pi}{\lambda} \times \frac{\lambda}{2}=\pi \\ Z_{\mathrm{in}} &=Z_{0}\left(\frac{Z_{L}+j 0}{Z_{0}+j 0}\right) \\ Z_{\mathrm{in}_{1}} &=Z_{L}=50 \Omega \\ \therefore \quad Z_{\mathrm{in}} &=\left(Z_{\mathrm{in}_{1}} \| 100 \Omega\right)=\frac{100 \times 50}{150}=33.3 \Omega \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 96 If the electric field of a plane wave is [latex]\vec{E}(z,t)=\hat{x}3 cos(\omega t-kz+30^{\circ})[/latex]- [latex]\hat{y}4sin(\omega t-kz+45^{\circ})[/latex] (mV/m), the polarization state of the plane wave is
solution: [latex]\vec{E}(z, t)=3 \hat{x} \cos \left(\omega t-k z+30^{\circ}\right)-4 \hat{y} \sin \left(\omega t-k z+45^{\circ}\right)[/latex] The plane wave is travelling in +z direction [latex] \begin{array}{l} \hat{E}_{x}=3 \cos \left(\omega t-k z+30^{\circ}\right) \\ \hat{E}_{y}=-4 \sin \left(\omega t-k z+45^{\circ}\right) \end{array}[/latex] At z=0, tracing E locus for various times [latex] \begin{array}{c} \text { At } t=0, E_{x}=3 \cos 30^{\circ}=3 \cdot \frac{1}{2}=\frac{3}{2}=1.5 \\ E_{y}=-4 \sin 45^{\circ}=-2 \sqrt{2}=-2.83 \end{array}[/latex] At [latex]t=\frac{T}{6} [/latex] [latex] E_{x}=3 \cos \left(\frac{2 \pi}{T} \times \frac{T}{6}+30^{\circ}\right)=0[/latex] [latex] E_{y}=-4 \sin \left(60^{\circ}+45^{\circ}\right)=-3.86[/latex] This is left elliptical polarized plane-wave.

question:
Question 97 Which one of the following field patterns represents a TEM wave travelling in the
positive x direction ?
solution: Since, the TEM wave or plane wave is travelling in  positive x-direction, then conditions should be [latex] \begin{aligned} P &=\vec{E} \times \vec{H} \\ \hat{a}_{x} &=\hat{a}_{y} \times \hat{a}_{z}\\ \text{or, }\quad\hat{a}_{x}&=\left(\hat{a}_{y}\right) \times\left(-\hat{a}_{z}\right) \end{aligned}[/latex] So, the option (B) satisfies the condition.

question: Question 98 To maximize power transfer, a lossless transmission line is to be matched to a resistive load impedance via a  [latex]\lambda/4[/latex]   transformer as shown. The characteristic impedance (in [latex]\Omega[/latex]) of the [latex]\lambda/4[/latex]  transformer is ___
solution: Input impedance for quarter wave transformer is given as, [latex] \begin{aligned} Z_{\text {in }}&=\frac{Z_{0}^{2}}{Z_{L}} \\ \text { Given: } Z_{\text {in }}&=50 \Omega, \quad Z_{L}=100 \Omega\\ \therefore \quad Z_{0}^{2}&=50 \times 100 \\ Z_{0}&=\sqrt{50 \times 100} \\ Z_{0}&=70.72 \Omega \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 99 The input impedance of a [latex]\frac{\lambda }{8}[/latex] section of a lossless transmission line of characteristic impedance 50 [latex]\Omega[/latex] is found to be real when the other end is terminated by a load [latex]Z_{L}=(R+jX)\Omega[/latex]. If X is  30 [latex]\Omega[/latex], the value of R(in [latex]\Omega[/latex]) is_____.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} Z_{\text {in }}&=Z_{0}\left(\frac{Z_{L}+j Z_{o} \tan \beta l}{Z_{o}+j Z_{L} \tan \beta l}\right)\\ \text{at }\;l&=\frac{\lambda}{8} \\ \Rightarrow \quad \beta l&=\frac{2 \pi}{\lambda} \times \frac{\lambda}{8}=\frac{\pi}{4} \\ \therefore \quad\tan \frac{\pi}{4}&=1 \\ Z_{\text {in }}&=Z_{o}\left[\frac{Z_{L}+j 50}{Z_{o}+j Z_{L}}\right] \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Given},\quad Z_{L}&=R+j X=R+j 30 \text{ and }Z_{0}=50 \Omega \\ 30 R &=80(50+R) \\ Z_{\text {in }} &=50\left[\frac{R+j 30+j 50}{50+j(R+j 30)}\right] \\ &=50\left[\frac{R+j 80}{(50-30)+j R}\right]=50\left[\frac{R+j 80}{20+j R}\right] \\ &=50\left[\frac{(R+j 80)(20-j R)}{20^{2}+R^{2}}\right] \end{aligned}[/latex] Since, only real part of [latex]Z_{\text {in }}[/latex] exists, so imaginary part of [latex]Z_{\text {in }}=0 [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \therefore \quad Z_{\text {in }} &=50\left[\frac{20 R+1600 j-j R^{2}+50 R}{20^{2}+R^{2}}\right] \\ \text { Zimaginary } &=0=\frac{1600-R^{2}}{20^{2}+R^{2}}\\ \therefore \quad R^{2} &=1600 \\ R &=40 \Omega \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 100 For a parallel plate transmission line, let v be the speed of propagation and Z
be the characteristic impedance. Neglecting fringe effects, a reduction of the
spacing between the plates by a factor of two results in
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} Z_{0}&=\sqrt{\frac{L}{C}} \text{ for parallel plate line}\\ \frac{C}{l}&=\frac{\epsilon W}{d} \text{ and } \frac{L}{l}=\frac{\mu d}{W} \\ \text{where}, \quad W&= \text{Width of the line}\\ d &=\text { Separation between the lines } \\ Z_{0} & \propto d \quad (Z_{0}\text{ change by half})\\ \text { Velocity } &=\frac{1}{\sqrt{L C}}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{\mu_{0} \epsilon_{0}}}=3 \times 10^{8} \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}\\ &\qquad\text{(No change in V)} \end{aligned}\\[/latex]

options.A: halving of v and no change in Z
options.B: no changes in v and halving of Z
options.C: no change in both v and Z
options.D: halving of both v and Z

question:
Question 101 In spherical coordinates, let [latex]\hat{a}_{\theta },\hat{a}_{\phi }[/latex]
 denote unit vectors along the [latex]\theta, \phi[/latex]  directions. [latex]E=\frac{100}{r}sin\theta cos(\omega t-\beta r)\hat{a}_\theta V/m[/latex] and [latex]E=\frac{0.265}{r}sin\theta cos(\omega t-\beta r)\hat{a}_\phi A/m[/latex] represent the electric and magnetic field components of the EM wave at large
distances [latex]r[/latex]  from a dipole antenna, in free space. The average power (W) crossing
the hemispherical shell located at r = 1 km, [latex]0\leq \theta \leq \pi /2[/latex] is ____.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \vec{E} &=\operatorname{Re}\left[\frac{100}{r} \sin \theta e^{-\beta r} e^{j \omega t}\right] \hat{a}_{\theta} V / m \\ &=\operatorname{Re}\left[\frac{0.265}{r} \sin \theta e^{-\beta \beta r} e^{j \omega t}\right] \hat{a}_{\phi} V / m \end{aligned}[/latex] Poynting vector, [latex] \vec{P}=\frac{1}{2} \operatorname{Re}\left[\vec{E} \times \vec{H}^{*}\right]=\frac{26.5}{2 r^{2}} \sin ^{2} \theta \hat{a}_{r} W / m^{2}[/latex] The average power crossing the given hemispherical shell is, [latex] \begin{aligned} \text { Power } &=\int_{0}^{\pi / 2} \int_{\phi=0}^{2 \pi} \vec{P} \cdot r^{2} \sin \theta d \theta d \phi \hat{a}_{r} \\ &=\frac{26.5}{2} \times 2 \pi \int_{\theta=0}^{\pi / 2} \sin ^{3} \theta d \theta \\ &=\frac{26.5}{2} \times 2 \pi \frac{2}{3}=55.5 \mathrm{W} \end{aligned}[/latex]

Question 103 A two-port network has scattering parameters given by [latex][S]=\begin{bmatrix} S_{11} &S_{12} \\ S_{21} & S_{22} \end{bmatrix}[/latex].  If the
port-2 of the two port is short circuited, the [latex]S_{11}[/latex]
 parameter for the resultant one port network is
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{l} b_{1}=s_{11} \cdot a_{1}+s_{12} \cdot a_{2} \qquad\ldots(i)\\ b_{2}=s_{21} \cdot a_{1}+s_{22} a_{2}\qquad\ldots(ii) \end{array}[/latex] When output is short, [latex]a_{2}=-b_{2} [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} -a_{2} &=s_{21} \cdot a_{1}+s_{22} a_{2} \\ \Rightarrow \quad a_{2} &=\frac{-s_{21} \cdot a_{1}}{1+s_{22}} \end{aligned}[/latex] Substituting in first equation, [latex] \begin{aligned} b_{1} &=s_{11} \cdot a_{1}+s_{12}\left(\frac{-s_{21} \cdot a_{1}}{1+s_{22}}\right) \\ &=\frac{s_{11} \cdot a_{1}+s_{11} \cdot s_{22} a_{1}-s_{12} \cdot s_{21} a_{1}}{1+s_{22}} \\ \frac{b_{1}}{a_{1}} &=s_{11}=\frac{s_{11}+s_{11} \cdot s_{22}-s_{12} \cdot s_{21}}{1+s_{22}} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 106 The return loss of a device is found to be 20 dB. The voltage standing wave ratio (VSWR) and magnitude of reflection coefficient are respectively
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { Return loss }&=-20 \log |\Gamma| \\ -20 \log |\Gamma|&=20 \\ \Rightarrow \quad|\Gamma|&=10^{-1}=0.1 \\ \text{VSWR}&=\frac{1+|\Gamma|}{1-|\Gamma|}=\frac{1+0.1}{1-0.1}=1.22 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 108 An infinitely long uniform solid wire of radius a carries a uniform dc current of density [latex]\overrightarrow{j}[/latex]. The magnetic field at a distance [latex]r[/latex]  from the center of the wire is proportional to
solution: We know that magnetic flux density at a distance r from the wire is, [latex]\begin{aligned} |B| &=\frac{\mu_{0} I}{2 \pi r} \\ \text { For } r \lt a \rightarrow I&=J \cdot \pi r^{2} \\ \text { so } \quad |B|&=\frac{\mu_{0} J r}{2}\\ |B| \propto r \text { for } r \lt a \\ \text { for } r \gt a,\quad I&=J \times \pi a^{2} \\ \text { So, } |B|&=\frac{\mu_{0} J \pi a^{2}}{2 \pi r} \\ |B| \propto \frac{1}{r} \text { for } r \gt a \end{aligned}[/latex]

options.A: [latex]r \; for \; r \lt a \; and \; 1/r^{2}\; for \;r \gt a[/latex]
options.B: [latex] 0 \; for \; r  \lt  a \; and \; 1 /r \; for \; r  \gt  a [/latex]
options.C: [latex] r \; for \; r  \lt  a \; and \; 1 /r \; for \; r  \gt  a [/latex]
options.D: [latex]0 \; for\; r \lt a \; and \; 1/r^{2} \;for \; r \gt a[/latex]

question: Question 109 The magnetic field along the propagation direction inside a rectangular waveguide with the crosssection shown in the figure is [latex]H_{z}=3 cos(2.094 \times  10^{2}x)cos(2.618 \times 10^{2}y)[/latex] [latex]cos(6.283 \times 10^{10}t-\beta z)[/latex] The phase velocity [latex]v_{p}[/latex] of the wave inside the waveguide satisfies
solution: From the given data [latex]\begin{aligned} \omega_{c} &=\left(\sqrt{\left(\frac{m \pi}{a}\right)^{2}+\left(\frac{n\pi}{b}\right)^{2}}\right) c \\ f_{c} &=(\sqrt{(2.09)^{2}+(2.618)^{2}}) \times \frac{3 \times 10^{10}}{2 \times 3.14} \\ &=16 \mathrm{GHz} \\ f &=\frac{6.283 \times 10^{10}}{2 \times 3.14}=10 \mathrm{GHz} \\ \text { Hence, } \quad f& \lt f_{c^{\prime}} \gamma=\alpha+j 0\\ \beta=0, \quad \quad v_{p}&=\frac{\omega}{\beta}=\infty \end{aligned}[/latex]
