Question 111 The radiation pattern of an antenna in spherical co-ordinates is given by [latex]F(\theta )=cos^{4}\theta ;0\leq \theta\leq \pi /2[/latex] The directivity of the antenna is
solution:
[latex]F(\theta)=\cos ^{4} \theta, 0 \leq \theta \leq \pi / 2[/latex] we know that directivity D is [latex] D=\frac{4 \pi u_{\max }}{\pi_{\mathrm{rad}}} \qquad\ldots(1)[/latex] [latex] \mathrm{F}(\theta) [/latex] is nothing but radiation intensity [latex] u(\theta, \phi)[/latex] and [latex] W_{\mathrm{rad}} [/latex] is radiated power. [latex] W_{\mathrm{rad}}=\int_{0}^{2 \pi \pi / 2} \int_{0}^{2} \cos ^{4} \theta \sin \theta d \phi\qquad\ldots(2)[/latex] above equation is written from the formula [latex] W_{\mathrm{rad}}=\iint_{\theta \phi} u(\theta, \phi) d \Omega[/latex] where [latex]\alpha \Omega[/latex] is solid angle and [latex]d \Omega=\sin \theta d \theta d \phi [/latex] So from (2) [latex] \begin{aligned} W_{\mathrm{rad}} &=\int_{0}^{2 \pi \pi / 2} \int_{0}^{2} \cos ^{4} \theta \sin d \theta d \phi \\ W_{\mathrm{rad}} &=2 \pi \int_{0}^{\pi / 2} \cos ^{4} \theta \sin \theta d \theta \\W_{\mathrm{rad}}&=-2 \pi\left[\frac{\cos ^{5} \theta}{5}\right]_{0}^{\pi / 2}\\
W_{\mathrm{rad}}&=\frac{2 \pi}{5}&\ldots(3)\\
\text { So, } \quad D&=\frac{4 \pi u_{\max }}{\left(\frac{2 \pi}{5}\right)}=10 u_{\max }=10\\
&\text { In } \mathrm{dB} \text { directivity }=10 \mathrm{log}_{10} \mathrm{D}=10 \mathrm{dB}\end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 114 A plane wave propagating in air with [latex]\vec{E}=(8\hat{a}_{x}+6\hat{a}_{y}+5\hat{a}_{z})e^{j(\omega t+3x-4y)}[/latex] V/m is incident on a perfectly conducting slab positioned at 0 [latex]\leq[/latex] x. The E field of the reflected wave is
solution: Incident wave propagation [latex]\rightarrow-3 \hat{a}_{x}+4 \hat{a}_{y} [/latex] Reflected wave propagation [latex]\rightarrow 3 \hat{a}_{x}+4 \hat{a}_{y} [/latex] [latex] E_{i} [/latex] incident direction [latex]\rightarrow 8 \hat{a}_{x}+6 \hat{a}_{y}+5 \hat{a}_{z} [/latex] [latex] \left.\begin{array}{l}E_{i} \text { tangential } \rightarrow 6 \hat{a}_{y}+5 \hat{a}_{z} \\ E_{r} \text { tangential } \rightarrow-6 \hat{a}_{y}-5 \hat{a}_{z}\end{array}\right\} E_{\text {tang }}=0 [/latex] [latex] \left.\begin{array}{rl}E_{i} \text { normal } & =8 \hat{a}_{x} \\ E_{r} \text { normal } & =8 \hat{a}_{x}\end{array}\right\} E_{\text {normal }}=E_{\max } [/latex] [latex] E_{r} [/latex] reflected direction [latex]=8 \hat{a}_{x}-6 \hat{a}_{y}-5 \hat{a}_{z}[/latex]

question:
Question 115 The electric and magnetic fields for a TEM wave of frequency 14 GHz in a
homogeneous medium of relative permittivity er and relative permeability [latex]\mu _{r}[/latex]=1 are given by [latex]\vec{E}=E_{p}e^{j(\omega t-280\pi t)}\hat{u}_{z} V/m [/latex] [latex] \vec{H}=3e^{j(\omega t-280\pi y)}\hat{u}_{x} V/m[/latex] Assuming the speed of light in free space to be [latex]3 \times 10^{8}[/latex] m/s, the intrinsic impedance of free space to be 120[latex]\pi[/latex], the relative permittivity [latex]\varepsilon_{r}[/latex] of the medium and the electric field amplitude [latex]E_{p}[/latex] are
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Given:}\quad\vec{E}&=E_{p} e^{i(\omega t-280 \pi y)} \hat{u}_{z} V / m\\ \vec{H}&=3 e^{i(\omega t-280 \pi y)} \hat{u}_{x} A / m \\ v&=3 \times 10^{8} \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex] From given expression we conclude that, [latex] \begin{aligned} \beta &=280 \pi=\frac{2 \pi}{\lambda} \\ \therefore \quad & \lambda=\frac{1}{140} \text { meter } \\ v &=f \lambda=14 \times 10^{9} \times \frac{1}{140} \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{se} \\ v &=1 \times 10^{8} \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{sec} \\ \text { but, } \quad v &=\frac{c}{\sqrt{\epsilon_{r} \mu_{r}}} \\ \therefore \quad 1 \times 10^{8} &=\frac{3 \times 10^{8}}{\sqrt{1 \times \epsilon_{r}}} \\ \therefore \quad \epsilon_{r}&=9\\ \frac{E_{P}}{H_{P}}&=\eta=\sqrt{\frac{\mu}{\epsilon}}=\sqrt{\frac{\mu_{0} \times 1}{\epsilon_{0} \times 9}}=\frac{1}{3} \sqrt{\frac{\mu_{0}}{\epsilon_{0}}} \\ \Rightarrow \frac{E_{P}}{3}&=\frac{1}{3} \times 120 \pi \\ \therefore \quad E_{P}&=120 \pi \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 116 A transmission line of characteristic impedance 50[latex]\Omega[/latex] is terminated in a load
impedance [latex]Z_{L}[/latex]. The VSWR of the line is measured as 5 and the first of the
voltage maxima in the line is observed at a distance of [latex]\frac{\lambda }{4}[/latex] from the load. The value of [latex]Z_{L}[/latex] is
solution: [latex]\text { VSWR }=5=\frac{1+|\Gamma|}{1-|\Gamma|}[/latex] [latex] \therefore |\Gamma|=\frac{2}{3} \Rightarrow \Gamma=\pm \frac{2}{3}[/latex] If maximum is at [latex] \lambda / 4 [/latex] from load then minimum will be at load itself. For the phase of [latex]\Gamma [/latex] [latex] 2 \beta x_{\max }=2 n \pi+\theta[/latex] where [latex]x_{\max }[/latex] is distance of [latex]V_{\max }[/latex] from load. [latex] \begin{aligned} 2 \cdot \frac{2 \pi}{\lambda} \cdot \frac{\lambda}{4}&=\theta \\ \Gamma&=-\frac{2}{3}\\ \text{Now},-\frac{2}{3}&=\frac{Z_{L}-Z_{0}}{Z_{L}+Z_{0}}=\frac{Z_{L}-50}{Z_{L}+50}\\ \Rightarrow Z_{L}&=10 \Omega \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 117 A current sheet [latex]\bar{J}[/latex] = 10[latex]\hat{u}_{y}[/latex] A/m lies on the dielectric interface [latex]x=0[/latex] between two dielectric media with [latex]\varepsilon _{r1}[/latex]=5, [latex]\mu _{r1}[/latex]=1 in Region-1 [latex] (x \lt 0) [/latex] and [latex]\varepsilon _{r2}[/latex]=5, [latex]\mu _{r2}[/latex]=2 in Region-2 [latex] (x \gt 0)[/latex]. If the magnetic field in Region-1 at [latex]x = 0^{-}[/latex] is [latex]\vec{H}_{1} = 3\hat{u}_{x}[/latex] + 30[latex]\hat{u}_{y}[/latex] A/m. The magnetic field in Region-2 at [latex]x = 0^{+}[/latex] is
solution: For magnetic field boundary relations are [latex]\begin{aligned} \vec{B}_{n_{1}} &=\vec{B}_{n_{2}} \\ \text { and } \vec{H}_{t_{1}}-\vec{H}_{t_{2}} &=-\vec{J}_{s} \times \vec{a}_{n} \\ \Rightarrow \quad B_{x_{1}}&=B_{x_{2}}\qquad\text{(x is normal component)}\\ \mu_{1} H_{x_{1}} &=\mu_{2} H_{x 2} \\ \Rightarrow \quad 1 \times 3 &=2 \times H_{x 2} \\ H_{x_{2}} &=1.5 \\ \Rightarrow \quad \vec{H}_{11}-\vec{H}_{t_{2}} &=-10 \hat{u}_{y} \times \hat{u}_{x}=+10 \hat{u}_{z} \\ \vec{H}_{t_{2}} &=H_{t_{1}}-10 \hat{u}_{z} \\ \vec{H}_{t_{2}} &=30 \hat{u}_{y}-10 \hat{u}_{z} \\ \Rightarrow \quad \vec{H}_{2} &=1.5 \hat{u}_{x}+30 \hat{u}_{y}-10 \hat{u}_{z} \mathrm{A} / \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 119 A transmission line of characteristic impedance 50 W is terminated by a 50 [latex]\Omega[/latex] load. When excited by a sinusoidal voltage source at 10 GHz, the phase
difference between two points spaced 2 mm apart on the line is found to [latex]\frac{\pi }{4}[/latex] radians. The phase velocity of the wave along the line is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { Phase difference }&=\frac{2 \pi}{\lambda} \text { (path difference) } \\ \Rightarrow \frac{\pi}{4}&=\frac{2 \pi}{\lambda}\left(2 \times 10^{-3}\right) \\ \therefore \quad &=8 \times 2 \times 10^{-3} \\ &=16 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{m} \\ f&= 10 \mathrm{GHz}=10 \times 10^{9} \mathrm{Hz} \end{aligned}[/latex] Hence the phase velocity of wave along the line is, [latex] \begin{aligned} & v=f \lambda=10 \times 10^{9} \times 16 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{sec} \\ \therefore \quad v &=1.6 \times 10^{8} \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 121 In the circuit shown, all the transmission line sections are lossless. The Voltage
Standing Wave Ration(VSWR) on the 60 [latex]\Omega[/latex] line is
solution: [latex]Z_{\text {in }}=Z_{0}\left(\frac{Z_{L}+j Z_{0} \tan \beta l}{Z_{0}+j Z_{L} \tan \beta l}\right)[/latex] Input impedance, [latex] \begin{aligned} Z_{1} &=30\left[\frac{0+j 30 \tan \left(\frac{2 \pi}{\lambda}\right)\left(\frac{\lambda}{8}\right)}{30+0}\right] \\ \Rightarrow Z_{1} &=j 30 \\ Z_{2} &=30 \sqrt{2}\left[\frac{30+j 30 \sqrt{2} \tan \left(\frac{2 \pi}{\lambda}\right)\left(\frac{\lambda}{4}\right)}{30 \sqrt{2}+j 30 \tan \left(\frac{2 \pi}{\lambda}\right)\left(\frac{\lambda}{4}\right)}\right] \\ &=30 \sqrt{2}\left[\frac{\frac{30}{\tan \pi / 2}+j 30 \sqrt{2}}{\frac{30 \sqrt{2}}{\tan \pi / 2}+j 30}\right] \\ &=60 \Omega \\ \text { or, } Z_{2}&=\frac{(30 \sqrt{2})^{2}}{30}=60 \Omega & \end{aligned}[/latex] Load impedance, [latex] Z_{L}=Z_{1}+Z_{2}=j 30+6[/latex] Magnitude of reflection coefficient, [latex]\begin{aligned} |\Gamma|&=\left|\frac{Z_{L}-Z_{0}}{Z_{L}+Z_{0}}\right|=\left|\frac{60+j 30-60}{60+j 30+60}\right|\\ &=\left|\frac{j 30}{120+j 30}\right|=\mid \frac{j 1}{4+j \mid} \\ &=\frac{1}{\sqrt{16+1}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{17}}} \end{aligned}[/latex] VSWR on 60 \Omega line, [latex] \text { VSWR }=\frac{1+|\Gamma|}{1-|\Gamma|}=\frac{1+\frac{1}{\sqrt{17}}}{1-\frac{1}{\sqrt{17}}}=1.64[/latex]

question: Question 122 A plane wave having the electric field components [latex]\vec{E}_{i}=24 \cos (3 \times 10^{8}t-\beta y)\hat{a}_{z} V/m[/latex] and traveling in free space is incident normally on a lossless medium with [latex]\mu =\mu_{0} [/latex] and [latex] \varepsilon =9\varepsilon_{0}[/latex] which occupies the region [latex]y\geq 0[/latex]. The reflected magnetic field component is given by
solution: [latex]\vec{E}_{i}=24 \cos \left(3 \times 10^{8} t-\beta y\right) \hat{a}_{z} \vee / m[/latex] The wave is travelling in +y direction. [latex] \begin{aligned} H_{i}=& \frac{1}{\eta}\left(\hat{a}_{y} \times \vec{E}_{i}\right) \\ =& \frac{24 \cos }{120 \pi}\left(3 \times 10^{8} t-\beta y\right) \hat{a}_{x} \\ =& \frac{1}{5 \pi} \cos \left(3 \times 10^{8} t-\beta y\right) \hat{a}_{x} \\ \frac{H_{r}}{H_{i}}&=\frac{\eta_{1}-\eta_{2}}{\eta_{1}+\eta_{2}}=\frac{\sqrt{\frac{\mu_{0}}{\epsilon_{1}}}-\sqrt{\frac{\mu_{0}}{\epsilon_{2}}}}{\sqrt{\frac{\mu_{0}}{\epsilon_{1}}}+\sqrt{\frac{\mu_{0}}{\epsilon_{2}}}} \\ =\frac{\sqrt{\epsilon_{2}}-\sqrt{\epsilon_{1}}}{\sqrt{\epsilon_{2}}+\sqrt{\epsilon_{1}}}&=\frac{\sqrt{9}-\sqrt{1}}{\sqrt{9}+\sqrt{1}}=\frac{3-1}{3+1}=\frac{2}{4}=\frac{1}{2} \end{aligned}[/latex] Therefore, reflected magnetic field component, [latex]\vec{H}_{r}=\frac{1}{10 \pi} \cos \left(3 \times 10^{8} t+\beta y\right) \hat{a}_{x}[/latex] Due to change in propagation direction to -y

question:
Question 123 The electric field component of a time harmonic plane EM wave traveling in
a nonmagnetic lossless dielectric medium has an amplitude of 1 V/m. If the
relative permittivity of the medium is 4, the magnitude of the time-average
power density vector (in W/[latex]m^{2}[/latex]) is
solution: Magnitude of the time-average power density vector [latex] \begin{aligned} P_{a v} &=\frac{E^{2}}{2 \eta} \\ \text { where, } \quad\eta &=\sqrt{\mu / \epsilon} \\ \eta &=\sqrt{\frac{\mu_{0}}{4 \epsilon_{0}}}=\frac{\eta_{0}}{2}=\frac{120 \pi}{2} \\ P_{a v} &=\frac{1^{2}}{2\left(\frac{120 \pi}{2}\right)}=\frac{1}{120 \pi} \mathrm{W} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 124 A transmission line has a characteristic impedance of 50 [latex]\Omega[/latex] and a resistance of 0.1[latex]\Omega[/latex]/m . If the line is distortion less, the attenuation constant(in Np/m) is
solution: For distortionless transmission line, [latex] \begin{aligned} L G&=R C \\ \Rightarrow \frac{L}{C}&=\frac{R}{G} \end{aligned}[/latex] Characteristic impedance, [latex] Z_{0}=\sqrt{\frac{L}{C}}=\sqrt{\frac{R}{G}}[/latex] Attenuation constant, [latex] \begin{aligned} \alpha &=\sqrt{R G}=\sqrt{R} \cdot \frac{\sqrt{R}}{Z_{0}}=\frac{R}{Z_{0}}=\frac{0.1}{50} \\ &=0.002 \mathrm{Np} / \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 125 If the scattering matrix [S] of a two port network is [latex]|S|=\begin{bmatrix} 0.2\angle 0^{\circ}&0.9\angle 90^{\circ} \\ 0.9\angle 90^{\circ}& 0.1\angle 90^{\circ} \end{bmatrix}[/latex] then the network is
solution: For reciprocal networks, [latex] S_{12}=S_{21} [/latex] For symmetrical networks, [latex] S_{11}=S_{22} [/latex] For antimetrical networks, [latex] S_{11}=-S_{22} [/latex] For lossless reciprocal networks, [latex] \left|S_{11}\right|=\left|S_{22}\right| [/latex] and [latex] \left|S_{11}\right|^{2}+\left|S_{12}\right|^{2}=1 [/latex]

[Hint : The algebra is trivial in cylindrical coordinates.]
solution: Applying [latex]\nabla \cdot H=J [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \nabla \times B&=\left|\begin{array}{ccc} \hat{a}_{x} & \hat{a}_{y} & \hat{a}_{z} \\ \frac{\partial}{\partial x} & \frac{\partial}{\partial y} & \frac{\partial}{\partial z} \\ \frac{-y}{x^{2}+y^{2}} & \frac{x}{x^{2}+y^{2}} & 0 \end{array}\right|=0 \\ J&=0 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 131 At 20 GHz, the gain of a parabolic dish antenna of 1 meter and 70% efficiency is
solution: [latex]\text { Gain }=\frac{4 \pi}{\lambda^{2}} A_{e}=\frac{4 \pi}{\lambda^{2}} \pi R^{2}[/latex] Along with illumination or efficiency [latex] \begin{aligned} \text { Gain } &=\eta \pi^{2} \frac{(2 R)^{2}}{\lambda^{2}}=7\left(\frac{D}{\lambda}\right)^{2} \\ &=0.7 \pi^{2}\left(\frac{1 \times 20 \times 10^{9}}{3 \times 10^{8}}\right)^{2} \\ &=30705.4359 \\ G(\mathrm{dB}) &=10 \log _{10} G \\ &=10 \log _{10}(30705.4359)=45 \mathrm{dB} \end{aligned}[/latex]

Question 140 The parallel branches of a 2-wire transmission line re terminated in 100[latex]\Omega[/latex] and
200[latex]\Omega[/latex] resistors as shown in the figure. The characteristic impedance of the line is [latex]Z_{0} =  50\Omega[/latex] and each section has a length of [latex]\frac{\lambda }{4}[/latex]. The voltage reflection coefficient [latex]\Gamma[/latex] at the input is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} Z_{\text {in }}&=\frac{Z_{0}^{2}}{Z_{L}} ; if l=\frac{\lambda}{4} \\ R_{1} \text{ due to }100 \Omega&=\frac{50^{2}}{100}=25 \\ R_{2} \text{ due to }200 \Omega&=\frac{50^{2}}{200}=\frac{25}{2} \\ \Rightarrow \quad R_{1} \| R_{2} &=25 \text { II } \frac{25}{2}=\frac{25}{3} \\ Z_{S} &=\frac{(50)^{2}}{25 / 3}=300 \Omega \\ \therefore \quad\Gamma&=\frac{Z_{S}-Z_{0}}{Z_{S}+Z_{0}}=\frac{300-50}{300+50}=\frac{5}{7} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 143 The [latex]\vec{H}[/latex] field (in A/m) of a plane wave propagating in free space is given by [latex]\vec{H}=\hat{x}\frac{5\sqrt{3}}{\eta _{0}}cos(\omega t-\beta z)+\hat{y}\frac{5}{\eta _{0}}sin(\omega t-\beta z+\frac{\pi }{2})[/latex]. The time average power flow density in Watts is
solution: For free space, [latex] \begin{aligned} P&=\frac{E^{2}}{2 \eta_{0}}, E=\eta_{0} H \\ P&=\frac{\eta_{0}^{2} H^{2}}{2 \eta_{0}}=\frac{\eta_{0} H^{2}}{2} \\ H&=\frac{1}{\eta_{0}} \sqrt{(5 \sqrt{3})^{2}+(5)^{2}}=\frac{10}{\eta_{0}} \\ P&=\frac{\eta_{0}}{2} \times \frac{100}{\eta_{0}^{2}}=\frac{50}{\eta_{0}} \text { watts } \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:

solution: 10V reflects to add to 30V in phase and gives 40V [latex] \begin{aligned} \Gamma &=\frac{V_{r}}{V_{i}}=\frac{10}{30}=\frac{1}{3} \\ \Gamma &=\frac{Z_{L}-Z_{0}}{Z_{L}+Z_{0}} \\ \Rightarrow \quad \frac{1}{3} &=\frac{Z_{L}-50}{Z_{L}+50} \\ \Rightarrow \quad Z_{L} &=100 \Omega \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 151 When a planes wave traveling in free-space is incident normally on a medium
having [latex]\varepsilon_{r}=4.0[/latex], the fraction of power transmitted into the medium is given by
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} P_{t}&=\left(1-\Gamma^{2}\right) P_{t} \\ \Gamma&=\frac{\eta_{2}-\eta_{1}}{\eta_{2}+\eta_{1}}=\frac{\sqrt{\frac{\mu_{0}}{\epsilon_{0} \epsilon_{r}}}-\sqrt{\frac{\mu_{0}}{\epsilon_{0}}}}{\sqrt{\frac{\mu_{0}}{\epsilon_{0} \epsilon_{r}}}+\sqrt{\frac{\mu_{0}}{\epsilon_{0}}}} \\ \Gamma&=\frac{\frac{1}{2}-1}{\frac{1}{2}+1}=\frac{-1}{3} \\ \tau&=1-\Gamma^{2}=1-\frac{1}{9}=\frac{8}{9} \\ \therefore \quad \quad P_{t}&=\tau \cdot P_{i} \\ \frac{P_{t}}{P_{i}}&=\frac{8}{9} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 152 A medium is divide into regions I and II about x = 0 plane, as shown in the
figure below. An electromagnetic wave with electric field [latex]E_{1}=4\hat{a}_{x}+3\hat{a}_{y}+5\hat{a}_{z}[/latex] is incident normally on the interface from region I . The electric file [latex]E_2[/latex] in region II at the interface is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \vec{E}_{t_{1}} &=3 \hat{a}_{y}+5 \hat{a}_{z}=\vec{E}_{t_{2}} \\ \vec{D}_{n_{1}} &=\vec{D}_{n_{2}} \\ \epsilon_{2} \vec{E}_{n_{2}} &=\epsilon_{1} \vec{E}_{n_{1}} \\ \vec{E}_{n_{2}} &=\frac{3 \times 4 \hat{a}_{x}}{4}=3 \hat{a}_{x} \\ \therefore \quad \vec{E}_{2} &=\vec{E}_{t_{2}}+\vec{E}_{n_{2}} \\ &=3 \hat{a}_{y}+5 \hat{a}_{z}+3 \hat{a}_{x} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 158 Two identical and parallel dipole antennas are kept apart by a distance of [latex]\frac{\lambda }{4}[/latex] in the H-plane. They are fed with equal currents but the right most antenna has a phase shift of +[latex]90^{\circ}[/latex]. The radiation pattern is given as.

[latex] \begin{aligned} E &=2 E_{0} \cos (\psi / 2) \\ \psi &=\alpha+\beta d \cos \theta \\ &=\frac{\pi}{2}+\frac{2 \pi}{\lambda} \cdot \frac{\lambda}{4} \cos \theta \\ \psi &=\frac{\pi}{2}+\frac{\pi}{2} \cos \theta \\ \psi=0 & \; \cos \theta=-1 & \theta_{\max }=180^{\circ} \\ \psi=\pi &\; \cos \theta=1 & \theta_{N P}=0^{\circ} \\ \psi=\frac{\pi}{2}& \; \cos \theta=0 &\theta_{\text{HPP}}=90^{\circ} / 270^{\circ} \end{aligned}[/latex] Option (C) when [latex]\theta[/latex] is considered as shown in array calculations

question: Question 164 A lossless transmission line is terminated in a load which reflects a part of the incident power. The measured VSWR is 2. The percentage of the power that is reflected back is
solution: [latex]\mathrm{SWR}=\frac{1+\Gamma}{1-\Gamma}[/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow \quad 2=\frac{1+\Gamma}{1-\Gamma} [/latex] Voltage reflection coefficient [latex] \Rightarrow \quad \Gamma=\frac{1}{3} [/latex] Power reflection coefficient [latex] \therefore \quad \frac{P_{\text {ref }}}{P_{\text {inc }}}=\Gamma^{2}=\frac{1}{9} [/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow 11.11 \%[/latex] of [latex]P_{i}[/latex] is reflected

question: Question 165 A plane electromagnetic wave propagating in free space is incident normally on a large slab of loss-less, non-magnetic, dielectric material with [latex]\varepsilon >\varepsilon _{0}[/latex]. Maxima and minima are observed when the electric field is measured in front of the slab. The maximum electric field is found to be 5 times the minimum field. The intrinsic impedance of the medium should be
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{SWR} &=\frac{E_{\max }}{E_{\min }} \\ \Rightarrow \quad s &=\frac{5 E_{\min }}{E_{\min }}=5 \\ & 5=\frac{1+|\Gamma|}{1-|\Gamma|}\;|\Gamma|=\frac{2}{3} \\ & \eta_{2}=\frac{120 \pi}{\sqrt{\epsilon_{r}}} \text { and } \eta_{2}=120 \pi \\ \text { As } & \eta_{2} \lt \eta_{1} \\ \Rightarrow -\frac{2}{3}&=\frac{\eta_{2}-120 \pi}{\eta+120 \pi} \\ \Rightarrow \eta_{2}&=24 \pi \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 167 If [latex]\vec{E}=(\hat{a}_{x}+j\hat{a}_{y})e^{jkz-k\omega t} [/latex] and [latex]\vec{H}=(k/\omega \mu )(\hat{a}_{y}+j\hat{a}_{x})e^{jkz-j\omega t}[/latex], the time-averaged Poynting vector is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \vec{P}_{\mathrm{avg}}=& \frac{1}{2} \text{Re}\left[\vec{E} \times \vec{H}^{*}\right] \\ =& \frac{1}{2} \text{Re}\left[\left(\hat{a}_{x}+j \hat{a}_{y}\right) e^{j k z-j \omega t}\right.\\ &\left.\times\frac{k}{ \omega\mu}\left(\hat{a}_{x}+j \hat{a}_{y} \right)e^{j k z-j \omega t} \right ]\\ \vec{P}_{\mathrm{avg}}=& \frac{k}{2 \mu \omega}[0]=0 \\ \left[\begin{array}{cc}1 &j\\-j&1\end{array}\right]=&1+j^{2}=1-1=0 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 169 Consider a 300[latex]\Omega[/latex], quarter-wave long (at 1 GHz) transmission line as shown in Fig. It is connected to a 10V, 50[latex]\Omega[/latex] source at one end and is left open circuited at the other end. The magnitude of the voltage at the open circuit end of the line is
solution: The [latex]\lambda / 4[/latex] line has [latex]Z_{\text {in }}^{\prime}=0 as Z_{L}=\infty [/latex] Current [latex]I_{\text {in }}[/latex] into the line [latex]=\frac{V}{50}=0.2 \mathrm{A} [/latex] Using current equation on the line [latex] I(x)=I_{\text {in }}=I_{L} \cos \beta x+\frac{j V_{L}}{Z_{0}} \sin \beta x[/latex] with [latex]x=\lambda / 4, I_{L}=0  \; as \;   Z_{L}=\infty [/latex] Open circuit end [latex] V_{L}=60 \mathrm{V}[/latex]

question:
Question 170 A parallel plate air-filled capacitor has plate area of [latex]10^{-4} m^{2}[/latex] and plate
separation of [latex]10^{-3}[/latex] m. It is connected to a 0.5V, 3.6 GHz source. The
magnitude of the displacement current is ([latex]\varepsilon =\frac{1}{36\pi}10^{-9} F/m[/latex])
solution: Displacement current, [latex] \begin{aligned} I_{d} &=A J_{d} \\ &=A \frac{\partial D}{\partial t}=A \in \frac{\partial E}{\partial t} \\ \left|I_{d}\right| &=|A \in \omega E|=A \omega \in \frac{V}{d} \end{aligned}[/latex] After putting values, we get, [latex] I_{d}=10 \mathrm{mA}[/latex]

question: Question 171 Consider a lossless antenna with a directive gain of +6dB. If 1 mW of power is fed to it the total power radiated by the antenna will be
solution:
When an antenna is lossless then the antenna
efficiency is 100%. In such case whole of the
power fed to antenna is radiated in the form of
radiation. Therefore, if power fed to antenna is
1 mW then total radiated power is also 1 mW.

question: Question 173 Two identical antennas are placed in the [latex]\theta =\pi /2[/latex] plane as shown in Fig. The elements have equal amplitude excitation with [latex]180^{\circ}[/latex] polarity difference, operating at wavelength [latex]\lambda[/latex]. The correct value of the magnitude of the far-zone resultant electric field strength normalized with that of a single element, both computed for [latex]\phi[/latex] = 0, is
solution: [latex]0 = 90^{\circ}[/latex] means XY plane means Z = O plane Far zone calculations of field at [latex]\phi[/latex] = O means point on X-axis. Angle made by the array axis to the point of consideration, if taken as [latex]\theta[/latex]. [latex] \begin{aligned} \text { Normalized array factor }&=2\left|\cos \frac{\psi}{2}\right| \\ \psi&=\beta d \cos \theta+\alpha \\ d&=\sqrt{2} s, \theta=45^{\circ}, \alpha=180^{\circ} \\ \Rightarrow 2\left|\cos \frac{\psi}{2}\right| &=2\cos\left[\frac{\beta d \cos \theta+\alpha}{2} \right ]\\ =& 2 \cos \left[\frac{2 \pi}{\lambda .2} \sqrt{2} \operatorname{scos} 45^{\circ}+\frac{180^{\circ}}{2}\right] \\ =& 2 \cos \left[\frac{\pi s}{\lambda}+90^{\circ}\right]\\ = & 2 \sin \left(\frac{\pi \mathrm{s}}{\lambda}\right) \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 174 A rectangular metal wave guide filled with a dielectric material of relative permittivity [latex]\varepsilon _{r}[/latex] = 4 has the inside dimensions 3.0 cm [latex]\times[/latex] 1.2 cm. The cut-off frequency for the dominant mode is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} v &=\frac{c}{\sqrt{\epsilon_{r}}}=\frac{3 \times 10^{8}}{2}=1.5 \times 10^{8} \\ f_{c} &=\frac{v}{\lambda_{c}}=\frac{1.5 \times 10^{8}}{6 \times 10^{-2}}=2.5 \mathrm{GHz} \\ \text { or, } f_{c} &=\frac{v}{2 a}=\frac{1.5 \times 10^{8}}{6 \times 10^{-2}}=2.5 \mathrm{GHz} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 175 A short - circuited stub is shunt connected to a transmission line as shown in fig. If [latex]Z_{0}[/latex] = 50 ohm, the admittance Y seen at the junction of the stub and the transmission line is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \beta &=\frac{2 \pi}{\lambda} \\ \text { For } Y_{d} & \beta d=\frac{2 \pi}{\lambda} \times \frac{\lambda}{2}=\pi \\ & Z_{d}=\frac{Z_{0}\left[Z_{L}+j Z_{0} \tan \beta d\right.}{Z_{0}+j Z_{L} \tan \beta d} \\ & Z_{d}=\frac{50[100+j 50 \tan \pi]}{(50+j 100 \tan \pi)}=100 \\ Y_{d}&=\frac{1}{Z_{d}}=\frac{1}{100}=0.01\\ For Y_{s} \quad \beta d&=\frac{2 \pi}{\lambda} \times \frac{\lambda}{8}=\frac{\pi}{4}, Z_{L} \rightarrow 0 \\ Z_{s}&=\frac{Z_{0}\left[Z_{L}+j Z_{0} \tan \frac{\pi}{4}\right]}{\left[Z_{0}+j Z_{L} \tan \frac{\pi}{4}\right]}=j Z_{0} \\ Y_{s}&=\frac{1}{Z_{s}}=\frac{1}{j Z_{0}}=-0.02 j\\ \therefore\quad Y&=Y_{d}+Y_{s}=0.01-0.02 j\end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 176 If the electric field intensity associated with a uniform plane electromagnetic wave traveling in a perfect dielectric medium is given by [latex]E(z,t)=10\cos (2\pi 10^{7}t-0.1\pi z)[/latex] V/m, then the velocity of the traveling wave is
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{l} \omega=2 \pi \times 10^{7} \\ \beta=0.1 \pi \end{array}[/latex] Comparing with [latex]A \cos (\omega t-\beta z) [/latex] [latex] v=\frac{\omega}{\beta}=\frac{2 \pi \times 10^{7}}{0.1 \pi}=2 \times 10^{8} \mathrm{m}[/latex]

question: Question 177 A uniform plane wave traveling in air is incident on the plane boundary between air and another dielectric medium with [latex]\varepsilon _{r}[/latex] = 4. The reflection coefficient for the normal incidence, is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \Gamma &=\frac{\eta_{2}-\eta_{1}}{\eta_{z}+\eta_{1}} \\ &=\frac{\sqrt{\frac{\mu_{0}}{\epsilon_{0} \epsilon_{r}}}-\sqrt{\frac{\mu_{0}}{E_{0}}}}{\sqrt{\frac{\mu_{0}}{\epsilon_{0} \epsilon_{r}}}+\sqrt{\frac{\mu_{0}}{\epsilon_{0}}}}=\frac{\frac{1}{\sqrt{\epsilon_{r}}}-1}{\frac{1}{\sqrt{\epsilon_{r}}}+1},\epsilon_{r}=4\\ &=\frac{-1 / 2}{3 / 2}=\frac{-1}{3} \Rightarrow 0.333 \angle 180^{\circ} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 178 If the electric field intensity is given by [latex]E = (xu_{x}+yu_{y}+zu_{z})[/latex] volt/m, the potential difference between X(2,0,0) and Y(1,2,3) is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} V &=-\int \vec{E} \cdot \vec{d} \mid \\ &=-\left[\int_{1}^{2} x d x \vec{u}_{x}+\int_{2}^{0} y d y \vec{u}_{y}+\int_{3}^{0} z d z \vec{u}_{z}\right] \\ &=-\left[\left.\frac{x^{2}}{2}\right|_{1} ^{2}+\left.\frac{y^{2}}{2}\right|_{2} ^{0}+\left.\frac{z^{2}}{2}\right|_{3}\right] \\ &=-\frac{1}{2}\left[2^{2}-1^{2}+0^{2}-2^{2}+0^{2}-3^{2}\right] \\ &=-\frac{1}{2} x-10=5 \mathrm{V} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 179 Medium 1 has the electrical permittivity [latex]\varepsilon _{1}=1.5\varepsilon _{0}[/latex] farad/m and occupies the region to the left of x = 0 plane. Medium 2 has the electrical permittivity [latex]\varepsilon _{2}=2.5\varepsilon _{0}[/latex] farad/m and occupies the region to the right of x = 0 plane. If [latex]E_{1}[/latex] in medium 1 is [latex]E_{1}[/latex] = [latex](2u_{x}-3u_{y}+1u_{z})[/latex] volt/m, then  [latex]E_{2}[/latex] in medium 2 is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \vec{E}_{1} &=2 u_{x}-3 u_{y}+1 u_{z} \\ \vec{E}_{1 t} &=-3 u_{y}+u_{z}=E_{2 t} &(x=0 \text { plane}) \\ \vec{E}_{1 n} &=2 u_{x} \\ \vec{D}_{1 n} &=\vec{D}_{2 n}=\epsilon \vec{E} \\ \Rightarrow \epsilon_{1} \vec{E}_{1 n} &=\epsilon_{2} \vec{E}_{2 n} \\ &=1.5 \epsilon_{0} \cdot 2 u_{x}=2.5 \epsilon_{0} \cdot \vec{E}_{2 n} \\ \vec{E}_{2 n} &=\frac{3}{2.5} u_{x}=1.2 u_{x} \\ \vec{E}_{2} &=\vec{E}_{2 t}+\vec{E}_{2 n} \\ \vec{E}_{2} &=-3 u_{y}+u_{z}+1.2 u_{x} \\ &=1.2u_{x}-3.0u_{y}+1.0u_{z} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 180 The depth of penetration of electromagnetic wave in a medium having conductivity [latex]\sigma[/latex] at a frequency of 1 MHz is 25 cm. The depth of penetration at a frequency of 4 MHz will be
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{l} \text { For conductors, } \delta=\sqrt{\frac{2}{\omega \mu \sigma}} \\ \qquad \begin{aligned} \delta \propto & \frac{1}{\sqrt{f}} \\ \frac{\delta_{2}}{\delta_{1}}=& \sqrt{\frac{f_{1}}{f_{2}}} \\ \delta_{2}=& \sqrt{\frac{1 \mathrm{MHz}}{4 \mathrm{MHz}}} \times 25 \mathrm{cm}=12.5 \mathrm{cm} \end{aligned} \end{array}[/latex]

question:
Question 182 A person with a receiver is 5 Km away from the transmitter. What is the distance
that this person must move further to detect a 3-dB decrease in signal strength?
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{l} \text { Signal strength }=\frac{P}{4 \pi R^{2}} \\ P_{1}=\frac{P}{4 \pi(5000)^{2}} \text { and } P_{2}=\frac{P}{4 \pi(x)^{2}} \end{array}[/latex] Given, [latex]\quad \frac{P_{2}}{P_{1}}=\frac{1}{2}[/latex] (3 dB decrease) [latex] \begin{aligned} \Rightarrow\left(\frac{5000}{x}\right)^{2}&=\frac{1}{2} \\ \Rightarrow \quad x&=5000 \sqrt{2} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex]Required distance [latex] =5000 \sqrt{2}-5000=2071 \mathrm{m}[/latex]

question:

solution: The surface change density is equally to normal flux density [latex] \begin{aligned} D_{\text {normal }} &=\rho_{s} \\ D &=\rho_{s}=\epsilon E=80 \cdot \epsilon \cdot 2 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 184 Distilled water at 25[latex]^{\circ}[/latex] C is characterized by [latex]\sigma[/latex] = 1.7 \times [latex]10^{-4}[/latex] mho/m and [latex]\epsilon =78\epsilon_{0}[/latex] at a frequency of 3 GHz. Its loss tangent [latex]tan\delta[/latex]
 is (  [latex]\epsilon=10^{-9} /(36\pi) [/latex] F/m)
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \operatorname{Loss} \text { tangent } &=\frac{\sigma}{\omega \in} \\ &=\frac{1.7 \times 10^{-4}}{2 \pi \times 3 \times 10^{9} \times 78 \epsilon_{0}} \\ &=\frac{1.7 \times 10^{-4} \times 9 \times 10^{9}}{3 \times 10^{9} \times 39} \\ &=0.13 \times 10^{-4}=1.3 \times 10^{-5} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 190 In a uniform linear array, four isotropic radiating elements are spaced [latex]\frac{\lambda }{4}[/latex] apart.
The progressive phase shift between the elements required for forming the main
beam at [latex]60^{\circ}[/latex] off the end-fire is:
solution: [latex]\theta_{\max }=60^{\circ}[/latex] from end fire means 60^{\circ} from array axis.\\ Condition for maximum, [latex]\psi \rightarrow 0 [/latex] [latex] \begin{array}{l} E_{T}=E_{O} \frac{\sin \left(N_{\psi} / 2\right)}{\sin (\psi / 2)} \\ E_{T}=N E_{0}=E_{\max } \\ \psi=\alpha+\beta d \cos 60^{\circ}=0 \\ \alpha+\frac{2 \pi}{\lambda} \cdot \frac{\lambda}{4} \cdot \frac{1}{2}=0 \\ \alpha=-\frac{\pi}{4} \end{array}[/latex]

solution: [latex]\frac{\lambda}{4}=\frac{492}{4}=123 \simeq L [/latex] [latex] \therefore \quad [/latex]It is a quarter wave monopole antenna. So, [latex]\quad R_{a}=36.5 \Omega[/latex]

question:
Question 192 A uniform plane electromagnetic wave incident normally on a plane surface of a
dielectric material is reflected with a VSWR of 3. What is the percentage of
incident power that is reflected?
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} s&=\frac{1+|\Gamma|}{1-|\Gamma|} \\ \Rightarrow 3&=\frac{1+|\Gamma|}{1-|\Gamma|} \\ |\Gamma|&=0.5 \\ \frac{P_{r}}{P_{i}}&=|\Gamma|^{2}=0.25 \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \therefore \quad 25 \% [/latex] of incident power is reflected.

question:
Question 193 A material has conductivity of [latex]10^{-2}[/latex]
 mho/m and a relative permittivity of 4. The
frequency at which the conduction current in the medium is equal to the
displacement current is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} |\sigma E| &=|j \omega \in E| \\ \sigma &=2 \pi f \epsilon_{0} \epsilon_{r} \\ \Rightarrow \quad f &=\frac{\sigma}{2 \pi \times \epsilon_{0} \epsilon_{r}} \\ &=\frac{9 \times 10^{9} \times 2 \times 10^{-2}}{4} \\ f &=45 \times 10^{6}=45 \mathrm{MHz} \end{aligned}[/latex]
